('44', 0, 5, 6, 245) 2. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('44', 0, 6, 7, 274) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Wednesday [On or before January 16, 1929] 2
('44', 0, 7, 8, 348) NARANDAS, You seem to have been hurt.
('44', 0, 7, 9, 386) I would have been happy to respect your wishes in regard to Chi.
('44', 0, 7, 10, 451) Santok 3, but I did not approve of your plan.
('44', 0, 7, 11, 497) For the manner of living of the mother and the daughters is so expensive that they would always have been a cause of discontent in the Ashram.
('44', 0, 7, 12, 640) Santok never liked the common kitchen, nor the inmates of the Ashram.
('44', 0, 7, 13, 710) About the khadi training section, I have already stated my view that neither suggestions can be supported.
('44', 0, 7, 14, 817) I see nothing wrong in the view that the Ashram and not an individual should have the agency.
('44', 0, 7, 15, 911) I shall decide finally on the 18th at the latest.
('44', 0, 7, 16, 961) I want you to take interest in all activities and participate in them.
('44', 0, 7, 17, 1032) Trust Chhaganlal.
('44', 0, 7, 18, 1050) He is a sincere and hard working man.
('44', 0, 7, 19, 1088) Do not mind his errors, but consider his motive.
('44', 0, 7, 20, 1137) About Sannabhai, I have simply said that Chhaganlal Joshi’s decision should be final.
('44', 0, 7, 21, 1223) For no one of whom the secretary does not approve should remain.
('44', 0, 8, 22, 1288) 1 Presumably a slip for “day before yesterday”; vide “Letter to Mirabehn”, January 1 4, 1929.
('44', 0, 9, 23, 1382) 2 Year inferred from the allusion to the problem of Santok; vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, December 19, 1928. As Gandhiji asked Narandas to see him on the 18th, the date of this letter could be fixed on the preceding Wednesday which was 16th January.

('44', 1, 5, 9, 1992) 3. AMERICAN PATRIOTISM
('44', 1, 6, 10, 2015) C. V. Rangam Chetty writes:
('44', 1, 7, 11, 2043) is the head of the American Mission Schools at .
('44', 1, 7, 12, 2092) He deputed Mr. .
('44', 1, 7, 13, 2109) , who was an Indian teacher in the Mission School at .
('44', 1, 7, 14, 2164) and who knows mechanism, to go to .
('44', 1, 7, 15, 2200) and bring materials for his motor car.
('44', 1, 7, 16, 2239) purchased German material which is cheaper and better than the American.
('44', 1, 7, 17, 2312) refused to touch it and said that he would not like to pay his money so far as possible to any nation except America.
('44', 1, 7, 18, 2430) then sold the material to a Brahmin gentleman at .
('44', 1, 7, 19, 2481) and purchased American material.
('44', 1, 7, 20, 2514) who was indifferent to my repeated requests to wear khaddar has now come forward to confess his folly and has resolved to wear khaddar in future after this incident.
('44', 1, 7, 21, 2680) I hope our educated and rich countrymen will take a lesson from the American and set an example to others.
('44', 1, 7, 22, 2787) I have purposely omitted names and places as they are not germane to my theme.
('44', 1, 7, 23, 2866) The point is quite clear.
('44', 1, 7, 24, 2892) Whether the Reverend gentleman referred to did not overstep the limit of patriotism is not the point to be examined.
('44', 1, 7, 25, 3009) The lesson Sjt.
('44', 1, 7, 26, 3025) Rangam Chetty wishes to draw from the incident is quite legitimate.
('44', 1, 7, 27, 3093) We, in our country, are in honour bound to prefer handspun khaddar to foreign cloth, no matter how inconvenient it may be to us.
('44', 1, 7, 28, 3222) It is flimsy philosophy that teaches us to go to the cheapest market irrespective of what happens therethrough to our next door neighbours.
('44', 1, 7, 29, 3362) Free donations of fine wheat from Australia or America will be poison to us, if that meant a workless India with her soil growing weeds instead of golden grain.
('44', 1, 7, 30, 3523) Similarly a free gift of cloth from Manchester would be too costly a bargain for India to accept.
('44', 1, 7, 31, 3621) I repeat, therefore, that khaddar is cheap at any price so long as it serves to utilize the idle hours of the nation and there is nothing else immediately in view to occupy them as usefully.
('44', 1, 7, 32, 3812) Young India, 17 1 1929
('44', 2, 0, 1, 3835) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 3
('44', 2, 1, 2, 3879) 4. THEN AND NOW
('44', 2, 2, 3, 3895) Some critics of the constructive resolution 1 passed by the Congress think that it is something new sprung by me upon a Cong ress that was eager for a vigorous, forward policy.
('44', 2, 2, 4, 4072) In the first place I claim no originality for my resolution, for, it closely follows the pres idential address.
('44', 2, 2, 5, 4184) In the second, it is identical with the now much lauded programme of 1920 21, 2 with certain desirable addi tions.
('44', 2, 2, 6, 4299) In 1921, as now, we had prohibition with picketing, we had kha ddar and boycott of foreign cloth with the burning demonstrati ons and we had untouchability campaign and Hindu Muslim unity.
('44', 2, 2, 7, 4488) The present pro gramme adds the amelioration of the status ofwomen and removal of kindred social abuses.
('44', 2, 2, 8, 4593) It also adds village reconstru ction and organization of city labour—surely, items that must find place in any constructive programme for the attainment of swaraj.
('44', 2, 2, 9, 4757) Is there not excitement enough in the programme, if Congres smen are serious about it?
('44', 2, 2, 10, 4844) Picketing of liquor shops, foreign cloth shops and collection and burning of foreign cloth are exciting enough for any worker and are enough to evoke all the resource fuln ess that the best workers may be capable of.
('44', 2, 2, 11, 5061) What, indeed, we have not in my resolution of the programme of 1920 21 is the boycott of legislatures, law courts and educational institutions and titles.
('44', 2, 2, 12, 5216) Nothing would please me better than to find these institutions that sustain the Government abandoned by the nation or at least Congressmen.
('44', 2, 2, 13, 5356) I know that then we should have swaraj and, what is perhaps more, we should have less corruption in the Congress than we now have.
('44', 2, 2, 14, 5487) But that time is not yet.
('44', 2, 2, 15, 5513) Congressmen assist legislatures, law courts and schools as much as any other, and perhaps during this year when the Congress works for the attainment of a constitution in accordance with the Nehru Report it must function through the legislatures.
('44', 2, 2, 16, 5760) In any event one year is not too much even for the most impatient independencewallah to organize for the quadruple boycott assuming, of course, that the Nehru Report status is not attained during the twelve months.
('44', 2, 2, 17, 5975) And if we are serious about
('44', 2, 3, 18, 6003) 1 Vide ”Speech on Constructive Programme, Calcutta Congress”, January 1, 1929. 2 Vide Appendix “Congress Resolution on Non Cooperation”, December 30, 1920.
('44', 3, 0, 1, 6159) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 3, 1, 2, 6199) complete severance of British connection, we shall, when the year is over, certainly cease to patronize the very institutions that are the emblems of British power and instruments for holding us under sub jection.
('44', 3, 1, 3, 6413) And is the present programme quite so tame as it is made to appear?
('44', 3, 1, 4, 6481) Was the picketing of liquor traps a tame affair?
('44', 3, 1, 5, 6530) Let Dr. Kanuga and his band of volunteers who were assaulted by angry liquor dealers and their myrmidons answer.
('44', 3, 1, 6, 6643) Let the hundreds of the prisoners in Assam answer who were mercilessly clapped into the Assam jails because they had the audacity to picket opium dens.
('44', 3, 1, 7, 6795) Was the burning of foreign cloth a tame affair?
('44', 3, 1, 8, 6843) Let Sarojini Devi who gave her very beautiful costly foreign scarf and many girls who gave up their rich foreign silks and other fineries they had learnt to treasure answer.
('44', 3, 1, 9, 7017) There is nothing to prevent Congressmen now from picketing liquor traps or opium dens or from collecting and burning foreign cloth.
('44', 3, 1, 10, 7149) Apart from the great social and economic value of these two very powerful items they have a political value of the very first order.
('44', 3, 1, 11, 7282) If we achieve boycott of foreign cloth we remove from Britain’s path the greatest incentive to greed, and if we stop the liquor and drug revenue, we force the rulers to reduce the ever growing military exp enditure.
('44', 3, 1, 12, 7498) These two things so easy to accomp lish, so well suited to employ the energy of a vast mass of people, I hold, will go a long way towards the fulfilment of the national purpose, if we can but accomplish them.
('44', 3, 1, 13, 7707) I claim that the programme is so catholic as to satisfy all tastes and to occupy the whole nation.
('44', 3, 1, 14, 7806) If we are many workers, we can take up all the items at once, if we are few, we may take up one item at a time.
('44', 3, 1, 15, 7918) There is, I admit, one important condition necessary to make the programme palatable, and that is, a living belief in non violence for the establishment of swaraj or Dominion Status or Independence, whichever the name we may give to our object.
('44', 3, 1, 16, 8163) It is not difficult to think out a programme that would immediately precipitate violence.
('44', 3, 1, 17, 8253) That however is beyond my ken or capacity.
('44', 3, 1, 18, 8296) Young India, 17 1 1929
('44', 4, 0, 1, 8319) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 5
('44', 4, 1, 2, 8363) 5. NOTES
('44', 4, 2, 3, 8372) REPORTED THREAT It is reported that the Government propose to take legal pro ceedings against those who strive for complete independence carrying severance of British connection with it.
('44', 4, 2, 4, 8559) It has further been suggested that organizations working for complete independence should be suppressed.
('44', 4, 2, 5, 8664) I am not aware of any law enabling the Government to punish the active advocacy of independence.
('44', 4, 2, 6, 8761) I wish the Gov ernment would take steps against the promoters of independence.
('44', 4, 2, 7, 8840) It will clear the political atmosphere and show what the Government mean by Dominion Status.
('44', 4, 2, 8, 8933) If it does not carry with it the power to sever con nection with the British, it is a form of bondage be it so mild.
('44', 4, 2, 9, 9050) An India, impatient of servitude and waiting to come to her own, will never be content with any form of bondage.
('44', 4, 2, 10, 9163) No national assembly can possibly be permitted to be the custodian of national honour, if it does not strive for the best that the nation is entitled to.
('44', 4, 2, 11, 9317) Any move on the part of the Government, therefore against the propaganda of indepen dence cum severance of British connection will precipitate the issue and undoubtedly give added strength to the severance movement.
('44', 4, 2, 12, 9533) As I have already remarked, we must have the power to sever the con nection even though we may never exercise that power.
('44', 4, 2, 13, 9655) Whether we should and would exercise that power or not will depend wholly upon how British rulers behave towards us during these critical times.
('44', 4, 2, 14, 9800) The school of severance must have the fullest liberty to vow and carry on its propaganda unhampered by any Governmental act, direct or indirect, open or secret.
('44', 4, 2, 15, 9961) The only honourable way to prevent the school from growing is to make the connection worthwhile for us to retain.
('44', 4, 2, 16, 10075) That can only be whenthe imperialistic spirit, the spirit of exploitation is killed and partnership on absolutely equal terms offered in the place of present bondage.
('44', 4, 3, 17, 10242) GUJARAT VIDYAPITH 1
('44', 4, 4, 18, 10262) This National Institution held its seventh convocation on 11th instant.
('44', 4, 4, 19, 10334) Acharya Ramadeva delivered the convocation speech in the place of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel who could not attend, but who sent his blessings and a spirited message reminding the graduates that their
('44', 4, 5, 20, 10532) 1 An article on this subject appeared in Navajivan, 20 1 1929.
('44', 5, 0, 1, 10595) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 5, 1, 2, 10635) education had only just begun.
('44', 5, 1, 3, 10666) Acharya Ramadeva’s was an impa ssioned address to show that the British educational system was devised to manufacture clerks, not statesmen, to make students ‘black Englishmen’ according to Macaulay, but not better Indians.
('44', 5, 1, 4, 10890) He had no difficulty in showing that the foreign method, grafted by foreig ners on the Indian, had resulted in terrible increase of illiteracy.
('44', 5, 1, 5, 11034) The Registrar’s report which was a businesslike document sho wed that the Vidyapith was still doing pruning work and strengthening its foundation.
('44', 5, 1, 6, 11181) Nevertheless it was able to show a literary output of no mean order in the shape of text books and research work done by the Puratatva Mandir with whose activity were identified scholars like Muni Jinvijayaji and Prof.
('44', 5, 1, 7, 11400) Dharmananda Kosambi and Pandit Sukh lalji.
('44', 5, 1, 8, 11443) The Vidyapith hopes inside of three months to furnish the Guja ratis with an authorized spelling dictionary, a want that is being increa singly felt.
('44', 5, 1, 9, 11593) Great stress is being laid upon manual training which is superstitiously believed to interfere with the development of the intellect.
('44', 5, 1, 10, 11727) The occasion was utilized by the graduates to present Acharya Kripalani with the khadi purse which the students had intended to collect and present to their popular Principal when he retired last year.
('44', 5, 1, 11, 11929) The purse contained over Rs. 6,000. Acharya Kripalani in thanking the students for their purse reiterated his promise to visit Gujarat from time to time and by citing his experience of the solid work being done by the old students among untouchables and Raniparaj showed that the Vidyapith had more than justified its existence.
('44', 5, 1, 12, 12258) Whilst he was proud of all the menial labour that these workers were doing with zest, he warned them against neglecting brainwork after leaving college.
('44', 5, 1, 13, 12411) He added that the marvellous work done by the Sardar of Bardoli could not have been done, if he had not combined great brain capacity with rare courage and equally rare powers of endurance.
('44', 5, 1, 14, 12601) The ‘old boys’ had their own function over which Sjt.
('44', 5, 1, 15, 12655) Kishor elal Mashruwala presided.
('44', 5, 1, 16, 12688) His thoughtful address reminded the stu dents of their serious responsibility and enjoined upon them the nece ssity of becoming true soldiers of swaraj.
('44', 5, 1, 17, 12841) I must not omit to notice the work being done by the students among the untouchables in the shape of night schools in the villages round Ahmedabad.
('44', 5, 1, 18, 12989) Through these night schools they are dealing with social evils, the drink curse and giving medical relief.
('44', 5, 1, 19, 13096) All honour to the boys who are thus patiently building brick by brick the swaraj structure.
('44', 6, 0, 1, 13188) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 7
('44', 6, 1, 2, 13232) LALAJI MEMORIAL AND SIND Sjt.
('44', 6, 1, 3, 13262) Jairamdas and other Sind friends pressed me whilst I was in Calcutta to go to Sind for the Lalaji Memorial collection.
('44', 6, 1, 4, 13381) I could not resist the temptation.
('44', 6, 1, 5, 13416) Though being pledged to tour for khadi I could not go to many places for this collection, I would not refuse the spor ting offer from Sind.
('44', 6, 1, 6, 13556) The collections for the Lalaji Memorial are creeping in, not pouring as they should have.
('44', 6, 1, 7, 13646) It would be a shame if the five lacs are not forthcoming within a reasonable time.
('44', 6, 1, 8, 13729) The donors have no excuse now for delaying, as they know exactly the purpose to which the collections are to be devoted.
('44', 6, 1, 9, 13850) I am hoping therefore that the response from Sind will be generous enough to serve as guide to the other provinces.
('44', 6, 1, 10, 13966) Nor must Sind forget khadi.
('44', 6, 1, 11, 13994) My visit to Sind has, I know, been long overdue.
('44', 6, 1, 12, 14043) Khadi lovers have been inviting me ever since my release from Yeravda to visit Sind for khadi propaganda and collecti ons.
('44', 6, 1, 13, 14166) Let them now prepare their offering for Daridra narayana.
('44', 6, 1, 14, 14224) And I expect the silk bedecked Sindhi ladies to think of their poor sisters as also to render me an account of their connection with the evil custom of deti leti.
('44', 6, 1, 15, 14387) Many of them promised to exert themselves to do away with it root and branch.
('44', 6, 1, 16, 14465) I hope that they will prove as good as their word.
('44', 6, 1, 17, 14516) Young India, 17 1 1929

('44', 7, 8, 21, 16174) If I do not tour in the U.P. in the near future and if you can come over to Sabarmati even for a day or two, we can discuss many things.

('44', 8, 5, 8, 16948) 9. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('44', 8, 6, 9, 16975) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 17, 1929
('44', 8, 7, 10, 17022) DEAR MOTILALJI, I have both your letters 1. No apology whatsoever is necessary for taking me to Calcutta.
('44', 8, 7, 11, 17128) Of course I had never expected to have to take such an active part in the deliberations as circumstances forced me to take.
('44', 8, 7, 12, 17252) But it was as well.
('44', 8, 7, 13, 17272) I was quite happy over it and it gave me an insight into the present working of the Congress organization which I certainly did not possess.
('44', 8, 7, 14, 17413) And after all, we have to battle both within and without.
('44', 8, 7, 15, 17471) The big Darbhanga case is a very heavy responsibility and it must take up a great deal of your time which would otherwise have been available for the constructive programme.
('44', 8, 7, 16, 17645) Nevertheless, I am glad you have this case and if it relieves you of all financial burdens, it will be possible for you then to give much more time to public work and that without a load of anxiety behind you.
('44', 8, 7, 17, 17855) Now as to the second letter.
('44', 8, 7, 18, 17884) If I am to finish the European programme, I may not put off the visit till May and I dare not keep the many friends who have invited me in a state of suspense up to the very time of my sailing.
('44', 8, 7, 19, 18078) And if I go at all I have to go to Germany, Austria, Russia, possibly Poland, France, England and I would like to add Italy, Turkey and Egypt though I have no invitations as yet from the last three places.
('44', 8, 7, 20, 18284) There are also pressing invitations from America

('44', 9, 1, 2, 18446) to include America if I go to Europe.
('44', 9, 1, 3, 18484) All these things I must settle now or not at all.
('44', 9, 1, 4, 18534) And your letter leads me to think that I must not think of undertaking the European tour this year at all.
('44', 9, 1, 5, 18641) The next will take care of itself.
('44', 9, 1, 6, 18676) Subject therefore to your reply, I propose to announce cancellation of the tour and make no promise for next year.
('44', 9, 1, 7, 18791) I have been asked to draw up a scheme for boycott of foreign cloth.

('44', 10, 5, 10, 20328) 11. LETTER TO DR.
('44', 10, 5, 11, 20346) M. A. ANSARI
('44', 10, 6, 12, 20359) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 17, 1929
('44', 10, 7, 13, 20406) DEAR MR. ANSARI, I have your letter.
('44', 10, 7, 14, 20443) I hope you have now got rid of your influ enza.
('44', 10, 7, 15, 20491) It was a marvel to me how some of us could get through the terrific strain of the work in Calcutta without coming to grief.

('44', 20, 1, 2, 34817) 27. “PRAN JAAYI ARU VACHAN NA JAAYI” 1
('44', 20, 2, 3, 34856) Tulsidas has put this vow in Ramachandra’s mouth.
('44', 20, 2, 4, 34906) Indian tradition abounds in examples where one’s pledge is held as dear as one’s life.
('44', 20, 2, 5, 34993) I hope the students of Gujarat College will add another example by keeping their pledge.
('44', 20, 2, 6, 35082) The conditions on which the Principal would permit them to study do not enhance his prestige nor do they ennoble the students if they agree to them.
('44', 20, 2, 7, 35231) In this there is an attempt to get a confession from the students as if they had committed an error instead of the Principal admitting his own.
('44', 20, 2, 8, 35375) The students deserve congratulations on not agreeing to such conditions.
('44', 20, 2, 9, 35448) It was their dharma not to agree to conditions.
('44', 20, 2, 10, 35496) They will be considered truly educated if they keep their pledge till the end.
('44', 20, 2, 11, 35575) And they will be regarded as having made a great contribution towards taking the country forward.
('44', 20, 2, 12, 35673) One need not doubt that such action by the students will have far reaching consequences.
('44', 20, 2, 13, 35762) The students’ victory does not consist in their returning to the college somehow, but in observing their pledge till their last breath.
('44', 20, 2, 14, 35898) If they thus learn the first lesson of honouring their pledge, they will in future be able to serve the country well, because they will have greater self confidence.
('44', 20, 2, 15, 36064) Moreover, to one who has cultivated self confidence, everything else in this world becomes easy.
('44', 20, 2, 16, 36161) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 20 1 1929

('44', 32, 1, 2, 52843) 49. WHY NOT K. S. ASSOCIATION?
('44', 32, 2, 3, 52874) If we have graduates’ associations, civil service associations and the like, why not Khadi Service Association or Khadi Sevak Sangha?
('44', 32, 2, 4, 53008) This service, if it is to succeed, should certainly be the most numerous in the world if not even the most important.
('44', 32, 2, 5, 53126) It is true that it will never bring the same remuneration as the other services which are only so called but which are based more or less, perhaps more rather than less, upon exploitation.
('44', 32, 2, 6, 53315) Khadi Service is a purely philanthropic agency and the servants are merely maintained on the principle that a labourer is worthy of his hire.
('44', 32, 2, 7, 53457) But in Khadi Service there is a higher satisfaction than that of pecuniary reward.
('44', 32, 2, 8, 53540) The satisfaction lies in the knowledge that the servant ministers to the needs ofthe neediest, the most helpless and the most numerous class of men in the country.
('44', 32, 2, 9, 53704) As this truth is being realized, khadi servants begin also to plan ways and means of consolidating their trust.
('44', 32, 2, 10, 53816) Hence at the usual weekly meeting of the Khadi Service candidates who are undergoing training at the Udyoga Mandir, late Satyagraha Ashram, the question of forming a Khadi Service Association was seriously discussed and it was resolved to form such an association.
('44', 32, 2, 11, 54081) To that end I invite all those who have received training at any of the institutions recognized by the All India Spinners’ Association to send to the Secretary, Udyoga Mandir, the following particulars: name in full, present address, age, whether married or single, children if any, where trained for Khadi Service, previous qualifications, present occupation, wages and such other information as may be useful for the proposed Association.
('44', 32, 2, 12, 54522) An early opportunity will be taken to form a provisional body and frame a provisional constitution.
('44', 32, 2, 13, 54622) The object of this body should be: 1. to promote contact and co operation among the men and women belonging to the Service, 2. to encourage them to make researches in khadi work in all its branches, 3. to help the needy members,
('44', 32, 3, 14, 54851) 4. to attract new members, 5. to hold periodical conferences with a view to compare notes and exchange experiences, 6. to devise methods of making khadi more popular from the Service standpoint.
('44', 33, 0, 1, 55046) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 33, 1, 2, 55087) These are only suggestions thrown out at random.
('44', 33, 1, 3, 55136) The first step will be to publish a directory of names and addresses of such servants.
('44', 33, 1, 4, 55223) The number of persons trained at the Ashram to date already comes up to 445. There is, no doubt, a large number trained by the other khadi organizations.
('44', 33, 1, 5, 55377) It will not be therefore an unpretentious direc tory by any means.
('44', 33, 1, 6, 55444) In sending names care, I hope, will be taken to send only those who are or were doing khadi work and have received adequate training and who have sought this service as volunteers, i.e., from the strictly philanthropic motive.
('44', 33, 1, 7, 55671) The desire of the promoters of the idea is to make the proposed association an efficient organization of true servants.
('44', 33, 1, 8, 55791) Writers will send their suggestions as to the condition of membership, objects, etc.

('44', 33, 3, 10, 55900) 50. DUTY OF RESISTANCE
('44', 33, 4, 11, 55923) The strike of nearly seven hundred students of the Gujarat College which has now gone on for over 20 days is no longer a matter merely of local importance.
('44', 33, 4, 12, 56079) A labour strike is bad enough, a students’ strike is worse whether it is justly declared or unjustly.
('44', 33, 4, 13, 56181) It is worse because of the consequences it entails in the end and because of the status of the parties.
('44', 33, 4, 14, 56285) Unlike labourers, students are educated and can have no material interest to serve by means of strikes, and unlike employers, heads of educational institutions have no interest in con flict with that of the students.
('44', 33, 4, 15, 56502) Students moreover are supposed to be embodiments of discipline.
('44', 33, 4, 16, 56566) A strike of students therefore produces far reaching consequences and can only be justified in extraordinary circumstances.
('44', 33, 4, 17, 56690) But though occasions for students’ strikes in well ordered schools and colleges must be rare, it is not impossible to conceive such as to warrant strikes on their part.
('44', 33, 4, 18, 56859) Thus for instance if a principal run ning counter to public opinion refuses to recognize a day of uni versal rejoicing as a holiday which both parents and their school or college going children may desire, students will be justified in declaring a strike for that day.
('44', 33, 4, 19, 57128) Such occasions will be more frequent in India as the students grow more self conscious and become more alive to a sense of their responsibility to the nation.
('44', 33, 4, 20, 57287) In the case of the Gujarat college I cannot help saying that so far as I have been able to judge, the students have had ample reason
('44', 34, 0, 1, 57420) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 35
('44', 34, 1, 2, 57465) for the strike.
('44', 34, 1, 3, 57481) It is quite wrong to say, as has been said in some quarters, that the strike has been engineered by a few mischievous students.
('44', 34, 1, 4, 57609) It is impossible for a handful of mischief makers to hold together seven hundred boys for over a fortnight.
('44', 34, 1, 5, 57717) As it is, there are responsible citizens advising and guiding the students.
('44', 34, 1, 6, 57793) Chief among these is Sjt.
('44', 34, 1, 7, 57819) Mavlankar, a pleader of experience and known for his wisdom and moderation.
('44', 34, 1, 8, 57895) He has been in touch with the Principal and is firmly of opinion that the students are absolutely in the right.
('44', 34, 1, 9, 58007) The facts can be briefly told.
('44', 34, 1, 10, 58038) The students absented themselves from college with the rest of the boys all over India on the Simon boycott day.
('44', 34, 1, 11, 58151) The absence was no doubt unauthorized.
('44', 34, 1, 12, 58190) The students were technically in the wrong.
('44', 34, 1, 13, 58234) They should have at least asked for formal permission before they absented themselves, But boys are the same all the world over.
('44', 34, 1, 14, 58363) One might as well hope to restrain the winds as hope to curb the roused enthusiasm of students.
('44', 34, 1, 15, 58459) Theirs was at best a youthful indiscretion.
('44', 34, 1, 16, 58503) This was condoned by the Principal after a great deal of negotiation, the boys being permitted optionally to appear for their terminal examination on a fee of Rs. 3 each, it being understood that the majority would appear and that those who did not would not be in any way punished.
('44', 34, 1, 17, 58786) The Principal, however, it is alleged, broke his pledge and put up notice making it compulsory for the boys to appear for the terminal examination upon payment of Rs. 3 each.
('44', 34, 1, 18, 58961) This naturally incensed the boys.
('44', 34, 1, 19, 58995) They felt: ‘if the salt loseth its savour, wherewith shall it be salted?, They therefore struck work.
('44', 34, 1, 20, 59097) The rest is simple.
('44', 34, 1, 21, 59117) The strike continues and friends and critics alike certify to the great self restraint and correct conduct of the boys.
('44', 34, 1, 22, 59237) In my opinion, students of a college are in duty bound to resist such breach of honour by their Principal as is alleged against the Principal of the Gujarat College.
('44', 34, 1, 23, 59403) It is impossible to tender to a teacher that unreserved respect to which he is entitled by reason of his honourable calling when he is found to be guilty of breach of honour.
('44', 34, 1, 24, 59578) If the students are resolute there can be but one end to the strike, viz., withdrawal of the offending notice and an absolute promise of immunity from any punishment to the students.
('44', 34, 1, 25, 59761) Indeed the most proper thing would be for the Government to appoint another Principal for the College.
('44', 34, 1, 26, 59864) There is in the Government Colleges too much of espionage and persecution of boys holding pronounced political views or taking any part in political gatherings not liked by the Government.
('44', 34, 1, 27, 60053) It is high
('44', 35, 0, 1, 60064) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 35, 1, 2, 60105) time that this unwarranted interference was stopped.
('44', 35, 1, 3, 60158) In a country groaning as India is under foreign rule, it is impossible to prevent students from taking part in movements for national freedom.
('44', 35, 1, 4, 60301) All that can be done is to regulate their enthusiasm so as not to interfere with their studies.
('44', 35, 1, 5, 60397) They may not become partisans taking sides with warring parties.
('44', 35, 1, 6, 60462) But they have a right to be left free to hold and actively to advocate what political opinion they choose.
('44', 35, 1, 7, 60569) The function of educational institutions is to impart education to the boys and girls who choose to join them and therethrough to help to mould their character, never to interfere with their political or other non moral activities outside the school room.
('44', 35, 1, 8, 60825) The question therefore raised by the strike of the Ahmedabad students is of first rate importance and they deserve the sympathy and support of other scholastic institutions and the public in general.
('44', 35, 1, 9, 61025) Parents are as much concerned with the strike as school going boys and girls.
('44', 35, 1, 10, 61103) For the Ahmedabad students have, I understand, acted throughout with the approval of their parents or guardians.
('44', 35, 1, 11, 61216) Young India, 2 4 1 1929
('44', 35, 2, 12, 61240) 51. NOTES
('44', 35, 3, 13, 61250) FOREIGN CLOTH AND KHADI The Working Committee of the Congress has passed a resolution asking me to frame a scheme for carrying out the Congress pro gramme regarding boycott of foreign cloth through khadi.
('44', 35, 3, 14, 61455) The scheme 1 as submitted by me to the Secretary is published elsewhere in this issue.
('44', 35, 3, 15, 61542) I commend it to the careful attention of the reader and invite him to offer suggestions for its improvement.
('44', 35, 3, 16, 61651) In my opinion boycott of foreign cloth is a comparatively easy thing to accomplish, if Congressmen would concentrate upon the effort with a will.
('44', 35, 3, 17, 61797) In order to enable them to do so a living faith in khadi is an absolute necessity.
('44', 35, 3, 18, 61880) If Congressmen still need conversion the scheme cannot be carried out.
('44', 35, 3, 19, 61951) I warned the Congress delegates as earnestly as I could against passing the resolution if they had no faith in the programme.
('44', 35, 3, 20, 62077) Notwithstanding the warning they passed the resolution without dissent and without protest.
('44', 35, 3, 21, 62169) That presupposes faith in khadi.
('44', 35, 3, 22, 62202) If they have it, the scheme is capable of being worked.
('44', 35, 3, 23, 62258) Let it be thoroughly
('44', 35, 4, 24, 62279) 1 Vide the following item.
('44', 36, 0, 1, 62306) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 37
('44', 36, 1, 2, 62351) understood that it is not possible to accomplish the boycott through any other means.
('44', 36, 1, 3, 62437) Let no one worry about the place of the indigenous mill cloth in the boycott.
('44', 36, 1, 4, 62515) This cloth has taken care of itself and will take care of itself.
('44', 36, 1, 5, 62581) What we need to do is to clothe with khadi those whom we reach.
('44', 36, 1, 6, 62645) If we speak with two voices, we shall fail in carrying out the boycott.
('44', 36, 1, 7, 62717) We shall succeed only in inflating the prices of indigenous mill cloth and in tempting unscrupulous mill owners to commit frauds upon a gullible public.

('44', 36, 2, 10, 63138) 52. SCHEME FOR BOYCOTT OF FOREIGN CLOTH THROUGH KHADI
('44', 36, 3, 11, 63192) Congress organizations should call for volunteers to go from door to door in every town and village having a Congress Committee and collect foreign cloth in the possession of the householders and deliver or receive orders for khadi required by such householders.
('44', 36, 3, 12, 63455) 2. All khadi should bear the stamp of the All India Spinners’ Association and prices should be distinctly marked on them.
('44', 36, 3, 13, 63577) 3. Voluntary preachers should be called for to popularize the use of khadi and to advocate complete boycott of foreign cloth.
('44', 36, 3, 14, 63703) Volunteers and preachers should know genuine from spurious khadi.
('44', 36, 4, 15, 63769) 4. Foreign cloth collected should be publicly burnt wherever possible.
('44', 36, 4, 16, 63840) 5. Foreign cloth dealers should be individually visited with a view to enlisting their help and inducing them to stop further purchase of foreign cloth and to cancel all cancellable orders.
('44', 36, 4, 17, 64030) 6. Picketing foreign cloth shops may be undertaken wherever possible and where there is no danger of violence being committed by Congress pickets, the latter being reliable and seasoned volunteers.
('44', 36, 4, 18, 64228) 7. All units should from day to day report to the Central Office details of work done in terms of the foregoing and the latter should circulate to the Press for publication a weekly digest of day to day progress.
('44', 37, 0, 1, 64441) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 37, 1, 2, 64482) 8. Help and co operation of all political and other organizations should be solicited in the campaign.
('44', 37, 1, 3, 64585) 9. Help of patriotic ladies should be enlisted to prosecute the boycott campaign.
('44', 37, 1, 4, 64667) 10. The All India Spinners’ Association should be asked to furnish the Central Office with a list of places where genuine khadi is available and to open stores where there is a demand for khadi.
('44', 37, 1, 5, 64862) 11. A small committee called Foreign Cloth Boycott Committee should be formed and entrusted with an initial fund with power to collect more funds.
('44', 37, 1, 6, 65009) The Committee should be under obligation to publish duly audited statements of income and expenditure every quarter.
('44', 37, 1, 7, 65126) 12. The Committee proposed in paragraph 11 should publish and distribute broadcast leaflets showing the necessity and possibility of boycott giving full details as to the method of achieving it by individuals.
('44', 37, 1, 8, 65336) 13. Resolutions should be moved in the provincial legislatures as well as the central calling upon their respective Governments to make all their cloth purchases in khadi irrespective of its so called costliness.
('44', 37, 1, 9, 65549) Resolutions should also be moved demanding a prohibitive duty on imports of foreign cloth.
('44', 37, 1, 10, 65640) The foregoing scheme is based upon the assumption that the Congress Committees all over India will be immediately reorga nized and that there will be handsome response to the call for memb ership and that there will be full co operation on the part of all Cong ress Committees in the prosecution of the campaign of boycott of foreign cloth through khadi.
('44', 37, 1, 11, 65995) It is suggested that if these conditions are fulfilled, it is possible to achieve this boycott during the year, at any rate to the extent of making a visible impression upon the imports of foreign cloth.
('44', 37, 1, 12, 66199) Young India, 2 4 1 1929

('44', 42, 5, 6, 71518) 61. LETTER TO MOTILAL NEHRU
('44', 42, 6, 7, 71546) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, January 2 4, 1929
('44', 42, 7, 8, 71583) DEAR MOTILALJI, I have your telegram.
('44', 42, 7, 9, 71621) After having written to you, I had almost reconciled myself to abandoning the proposed European tour and, now that you have reconsidered your decision, there is a disinclination on my part to undertake the tour.
('44', 42, 7, 10, 71833) I feel that if we are to do anything next year, 1 as we ought to, I may not absent myself from India during the year, but should do whatever I can to assist to make the way clear for next year’s battle.
('44', 42, 7, 11, 72036) Having moved the constructive programme resolution 2, I almost feel [it] like running away if there is any work that I can do in the country.
('44', 42, 7, 12, 72178) If I leave at the end of April, I do not expect to return before the middle of October.
('44', 42, 7, 13, 72266) If then, that is, if I am to go through the long programme sketched by me in my previous letter 3, more especially if I am to throw in America.
('44', 42, 7, 14, 72410) The more, therefore, I contemplate the European tour, the more disinclined I feel like facing it this year.
('44', 42, 7, 15, 72518) Next year, of course, may be out of question.
('44', 42, 7, 16, 72564) I am, therefore, just now on the horns of a dilemma.
('44', 42, 7, 17, 72617) I do not want to tax you any further in the matter and I know that I must now decide for myself.
('44', 42, 7, 18, 72714) But if anything occurs to you, you will please let me know.
('44', 42, 7, 19, 72774) I am now conferring with Vallabhbhai, Jamnalalji, Rajagopalachari and others and hope to decide finally in a few days.

('44', 51, 6, 12, 85518) In any constitution that I could endorse, I should certainly be against the confiscation of the legitimate rights of any community.
('44', 51, 6, 13, 85650) I would however put stress upon the word ‘legitimate’.
('44', 51, 6, 14, 85705) There are many privi leges enjoyed by those who belong to the ruling race which privileges have not been legitimately earned.
('44', 51, 6, 15, 85831) If therefore I had my way, I should most decidedly examine every such privilege and those which are discovered not to have been legitimately obtained should be taken away.
('44', 51, 7, 16, 86003) Yours sincerely, J. D. JENKINS, ESQ.

('44', 54, 1, 2, 89424) from Sind, he will come to Allahabad to wind up his home and to prepare the papers for handing over charge and the balance sheet to date so that whenever Kripalani is ready to go there he can take charge.
('44', 54, 1, 3, 89629) I wish you will not listen to doctors when they object to the Indian sun.
('44', 54, 1, 4, 89703) You have heard of Dr. Muthu.
('44', 54, 1, 5, 89732) Revashankerbhai’s son Dhiru was suffering from tuberculosis of the bone.
('44', 54, 1, 6, 89805) After having tried sanatorium cure in Solon and all the doctors he could get hold of in Bombay, he sent for Dr. Muthu, paid him a fee of thousand rupees per day.
('44', 54, 1, 7, 89967) Dr. Muthu had no better advice to offer than to prescribe open air, light food and sun treatment.
('44', 54, 1, 8, 90065) The affected bone was discharging some time one pound of pus per day.
('44', 54, 1, 9, 90135) The affected bone had to be exposed to the sun every morning for a few hours and he had to lie in the open air the whole day long.
('44', 54, 1, 10, 90266) He was not even sent to a sanatorium.
('44', 54, 1, 11, 90304) He is now completely cured.
('44', 54, 1, 12, 90332) European sun may be better, but the Indian rival is by no means to be despised.
('44', 54, 1, 13, 90412) Doctors here suggest the morning sun.
('44', 54, 1, 14, 90450) They say that ultra violet rays are best taken between 8 and 10 o’clock and in summer between 7 and 8. But it really depends upon the patient’s condition.
('44', 54, 2, 15, 90605) Yours sincerely,

('44', 55, 5, 7, 91607) 80. MY NOTES
('44', 55, 6, 8, 91620) STUDENTS AND THE STRIKE
('44', 55, 7, 9, 91644) As this strike drags on, the students are being tested.
('44', 55, 7, 10, 91700) The fact that they have so far remained resolute does credit to them and takes the country forward.
('44', 55, 7, 11, 91800) Now I feel inclined to suggest to them that they should do some work.
('44', 55, 7, 12, 91870) Why should they not clean the lanes of Ahmedabad ?
('44', 55, 7, 13, 91921) They should have confidence that ultimately they will attend the same college honourably.
('44', 55, 7, 14, 92011) The time is now approaching when the Principal himself will have to quit.
('44', 55, 7, 15, 92085) In order to acquire this much strength, it is necessary for the students to engage themselves in social service.
('44', 55, 7, 16, 92198) There is a Congress resolution that the boycott of foreign cloth should be effected through khadi.
('44', 55, 7, 17, 92297) Will they not give up foreign cloth?
('44', 55, 7, 18, 92334) Will they not collect it from others?
('44', 55, 7, 19, 92372) Will they not wear khadi?
('44', 55, 7, 20, 92398) Will they not sell khadi from door to door?
('44', 55, 7, 21, 92442) Students should give thought to these questions.
('44', 55, 8, 22, 92491) SILENCE DURING SPINNING
('44', 55, 9, 23, 92515) One who does sacrificial spinning writes to say: 1
('44', 55, 10, 24, 92566) I was unaware that silence could mean what this writer has interpreted it to mean.
('44', 55, 10, 25, 92649) In recommending silence I implied that no one should gossip with those sitting around.
('44', 55, 10, 26, 92736) I certainly did not imply that he who maintained silence should not sing a bhajan about Rama in his heart.
('44', 55, 10, 27, 92843) Moreover, he who cannot thus repeat the name of Rama in his heart should certainly do so with his tongue.
('44', 55, 10, 28, 92949) Since the example of a water lift has been cited, I consider it necessary to make it clear that the bhajan which the farmer sings will have a good effect on a cultured listener, but we cannot assume that the same is always true of the peasant.
('44', 55, 10, 29, 93193) His lips sing the bhajan by force of habit but his mind
('44', 55, 11, 30, 93249) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('44', 55, 11, 31, 93286) The correspondent, mentioning the bhajans or devotional songs that a farmer used to sing while lifting water from the well, had asked Gandhiji why he had advised maintenance of silence during spinning and not singing bhajans or repeating Ramanama.
('44', 56, 0, 1, 93534) VOL.44 :16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 57
('44', 56, 1, 2, 93579) may well be wandering elsewhere at that time.
('44', 56, 1, 3, 93625) Hence we cannot acquit ourselves by singing bhajans aloud while spinning.
('44', 56, 1, 4, 93699) It is only when the tongue is always in tune with the heart that the singing of a bhajan may be regarded as worth while.
('44', 56, 1, 5, 93820) If we do not keep this in mind, we should assume with the poet that “all means become so many obstacles”.
('44', 56, 1, 6, 93926) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 27 1 1929
('44', 56, 2, 7, 93963) 81. HOW TO INCREASE THE SALE OF KHADI
('44', 56, 3, 8, 94001) In the Khadi Patrika Shri Vithaldas Jerajani has made an important suggestion about increasing the sale of khadi, from which I give the following extracts: 1
('44', 56, 4, 9, 94159) This certainly is one way.
('44', 56, 4, 10, 94186) I feel like suggesting another which springs from it.
('44', 56, 4, 11, 94240) Any merchant in a village who wishes to invest even a small sum should buy khadi worth Rs. 10 or more on condition that if he could not sell it within a month he would return it at his own cost to the khadi bhandar.
('44', 56, 4, 12, 94456) Even those who are not merchants but are desirous of doing this business can do so.
('44', 56, 4, 13, 94540) In this there is no risk involved for either party and khadi can be propagated easily.
('44', 56, 4, 14, 94627) A number of good and bad things have thus been propagated in the world.
('44', 56, 4, 15, 94699) Within no time tea has been made popular all over India by taking it within easy reach of every home.
('44', 56, 4, 16, 94801) But this is propaganda for a vice.
('44', 56, 4, 17, 94836) This has resulted in nothing but a loss for the people.
('44', 56, 4, 18, 94892) In khadi propaganda, the propagandist, the buyer and the thing — all three stand to gain and yet we do not find many persons willing to carry on this propaganda.
('44', 56, 4, 19, 95054) In these circumstances, if there are a number of people willing to invest a capital of Rs. 10 and forgo interest on it, even then we should feel contented.
('44', 56, 4, 20, 95210) But I must admit that there is a problem involved in this suggestion.
('44', 56, 4, 21, 95280) If one man offers a hundred rupees and suggests that khadi worth ten rupees be propagated in ten villages, we can hardly afford to take those hundred rupees and our object too will not be served.
('44', 56, 4, 22, 95476) My suggestion in effect emphasizes the necessity of having village workers only and the condition is that every one of them should invest a capital of ten rupees.
('44', 56, 4, 23, 95639) This is because only if such persons are available, can they carry on propaganda for khadi in
('44', 56, 5, 24, 95733) 1 These are not translated here.
('44', 56, 5, 25, 95766) The correspondent had listed various facilities offered to traders by the Khadi Bhandar, Bombay.
('44', 57, 0, 1, 95863) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 58
('44', 57, 1, 2, 95904) villages.
('44', 57, 1, 3, 95914) That is to say, my suggestion envisages the search not for those who can donate a hundred rupees or more, but for khadi lovers of one or more villages who will invest ten rupees of their own or those secured from their friends by virtue of their status and keep doing propaganda for khadi with that amount.
('44', 57, 1, 4, 96221) Let Shri Vithaldas and all other lovers of khadi make this search.

('44', 67, 3, 9, 114207) 94. MY APOLOGIES
('44', 67, 4, 10, 114224) Circumstances permitting, I had fully intended to undertake my long talked of European tour early this year.
('44', 67, 4, 11, 114333) But after the most careful consideration and consultation with friends I have come to the conclusion that the circumstances compel me to give up the tour for this year at any rate.
('44', 67, 4, 12, 114514) I dare not think of the next.
('44', 67, 4, 13, 114544) A dear Danish friend writes to me saying I could usefully go to Europe only as a represen tative of free India.
('44', 67, 4, 14, 114656) I feel the truth of the remark.
('44', 67, 4, 15, 114688) But that is by the way.
('44', 67, 4, 16, 114712) Pandit Motilalji, to whom I had mentioned the matter in Cal cutta, whilst he at first thought I should not go, has telegraphed withdrawing his objection, pressing me to fulfil the ‘elaborate Euro pean programme’ of which I had given him a rough idea.
('44', 67, 4, 17, 114963) But now that I have freedom of action from him, my courage fails me.
('44', 67, 4, 18, 115032) I have no voice from within prompting me to go.
('44', 67, 4, 19, 115080) On the contrary, having put the constructive resolution before the Congress and having received universal support, I feel that I would be guilty of desertion if I now went away to Europe.
('44', 67, 4, 20, 115268) It may be that those who voted for the resolution never meant to carry it out.
('44', 67, 4, 21, 115347) It may be that I shall have to do nothing during the year in respect of the programme.
('44', 67, 4, 22, 115434) But I feel that it is not for me to reason thus.
('44', 67, 4, 23, 115483) I must not lose faith in the workers.
('44', 67, 4, 24, 115521) I must, like the immortal Barkis, be ever ‘willing’.

('44', 68, 1, 4, 115920) Though one year’s limit was not of my seeking, though I considered it to be too short a notice for the nation and for the British people, I could not make it a point of principle on which to break.

('44', 80, 1, 2, 138319) 108. STUDENTS OF GUJARAT COLLEGE
('44', 80, 2, 3, 138352) As the students—both boys and girls–of Gujarat College gain glory day by day, their responsibility too increases.
('44', 80, 2, 4, 138466) To the extent their strike drags on and their determination increasingly attracts the entire country’s attention, the people’s expectations of them rise also.
('44', 80, 2, 5, 138625) This is exactly like what happened in Bardoli.
('44', 80, 2, 6, 138672) One can say that at the outset the strike concerned the students alone.
('44', 80, 2, 7, 138744) Now it concerns the whole of India.
('44', 80, 2, 8, 138780) Hence they cannot relax now.
('44', 80, 2, 9, 138809) I hear from all quarters that the majority of students will never break their pledge.
('44', 80, 2, 10, 138895) Nevertheless, in accordance with the saying, “The wary is always happy”, I do not think it is discourteous to sound a note of warning that the students should remain vigilant and should not succumb to any kind of temptation or fear.
('44', 80, 2, 11, 139128) It is only if the students jointly undertake some constructive work that this strike will bring about the best result.
('44', 80, 2, 12, 139247) There are many such tasks.
('44', 80, 2, 13, 139274) A letter from a citizen of Ahmedabad about the insanitary condition of the city appears in this very issue.
('44', 80, 2, 14, 139382) 1 This gives an adequate description of the filth there.
('44', 80, 2, 15, 139439) Along with that letter the writer sent figures of the rate of child mortality which should put us to shame, but I do not publish them because they are well known.
('44', 80, 2, 16, 139602) The president of the Youth League, Dr. Hariprasad [Desai], has himself given them publicity.
('44', 80, 2, 17, 139695) The students can easily undertake the job of removing this filth.
('44', 80, 2, 18, 139761) By showing the people ways of doing away with such dirt they can promote the city’s health.
('44', 80, 2, 19, 139853) There is altruism as well as glory in this work.
('44', 80, 2, 20, 139902) Some such work will serve as an example to every student in India.
('44', 80, 2, 21, 139969) They will earn the blessings of the citizens and I believe this is one fine way of bringing the strike to an early end.
('44', 80, 2, 22, 140089) As long as the students do not engage themselves in some work, the danger of their falling and Mr. Shirras too will attempt to beat them down.
('44', 80, 2, 23, 140232) This much is clear that the students cannot spend a long time in merely listening to speeches and lectures.
('44', 80, 2, 24, 140340) Now every step must be taken on the assumption that the strike will drag on.
('44', 80, 2, 25, 140417) It is proper and necessary that we should be ready for a settlement.
('44', 80, 2, 26, 140486) We should not take any drastic step that would preclude a settlement for ever.
('44', 80, 2, 27, 140565) Likewise we cannot sit idle waiting for a compromise.
('44', 80, 2, 28, 140619) Assuring themselves that it

('44', 81, 0, 1, 140683) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 82
('44', 81, 1, 2, 140724) will come off honourably at the proper time, the students should not worry about it and should now throw themselves whole heartedly into work.

('44', 82, 1, 2, 142877) above clause to those whom we regard as untouchables, is improper.

('44', 82, 2, 8, 143592) SLUMS OF AHMEDABAD
('44', 82, 3, 9, 143611) A citizen writes 1 about the slums of Ahmedabad to which Dr. Hariprased has given publicity: Every citizen, man and woman, needs to ponder over this letter.
('44', 82, 3, 10, 143768) There is nothing new in it.
('44', 82, 3, 11, 143796) Nor is what is already known put here in a new form; yet this letter draws attention to something we know.
('44', 82, 3, 12, 143903) As the insanitary conditions in Ahmedabad are such as to arouse shame in the Municipality and the citizens, any amount of attention paid to it cannot be regarded as too much.
('44', 82, 3, 13, 144078) If we cannot keep clean our own courtyard, how then can we help in keeping the entire country clean?
('44', 82, 3, 14, 144179) If we leave our courtyard stinking, then there is every chance of a foul stench arising from our swaraj.
('44', 82, 3, 15, 144284) Therefore, it is the duty of the Mun icipality and the citizens of Ahmedabad to adopt ways and means of clearing up this filth.
('44', 82, 3, 16, 144412) It is possible that many who have got used to this filth may like to tolerate it, but to continue such a slumber in this age of purification should be a matter of shame.
('44', 82, 3, 17, 144582) The fact that there is an economic loss in preserving this filth is something which should be understood by the wealthy citizens of Ahmedabad.
('44', 82, 3, 18, 144725) Because, diseases spread fast owing to uncleanliness and lead to loss of manpower.
('44', 82, 3, 19, 144808) When an inanimate engine stops working we start calculating the loss caused by this stoppage.
('44', 82, 3, 20, 144902) The body is a living engine and when it stops working there is a twofold loss.
('44', 82, 3, 21, 144981) Idleness following illness is one loss and another is the cost of medical treatment.
('44', 82, 3, 22, 145066) And the individual’s loss
('44', 82, 4, 23, 145092) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('44', 82, 4, 24, 145129) The correspondent had described the foul conditions prevailing in Ahmedabad and his own unsuccessful efforts to improve them.
('44', 82, 4, 25, 145255) He wanted that children in primary schools should be given lessons in cleanliness.
('44', 83, 0, 1, 145338) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 84
('44', 83, 1, 2, 145379) should be regarded in the final calculation as a loss of public wealth.
('44', 83, 1, 3, 145451) In the above letter a suggestion has been made to educate pupils in schools about hygiene.
('44', 83, 1, 4, 145542) This is worth welcoming.
('44', 83, 1, 5, 145567) If all the students of Ahmedabad, who are mature, are invited to work for cleaning up the city’s filth, and if after forming them into batches, the teachers set out with brooms and buckets, they can change the appearance of Ahmedabad in no time and the students will readily receive practical and real education.

('44', 83, 4, 8, 145916) 110. A YOUNG MAN’S DILEMMA 1
('44', 83, 5, 9, 145945) A Patidar young man writes:
('44', 83, 6, 10, 145973) My parents want me to be married this very year and insist on my obeying their wishes in this respect.
('44', 83, 6, 11, 146076) In my community no one can secure a bride without conforming to the condition of sata, i.e., without offering a girl
('44', 83, 7, 12, 146193) of one’s family in exchange.
('44', 83, 7, 13, 146222) Child marriage is the rule.
('44', 83, 7, 14, 146250) In my case too girls of nine or ten years of age are only are available and that too on the condition that we conform to the condition of sata.
('44', 83, 7, 15, 146394) My father says that even this may
('44', 83, 8, 16, 146428) not be possible afterwards, if we miss the opportunity this year.
('44', 83, 8, 17, 146494) If I say ‘no’ my mother weeps and creates no end of trouble in the family.
('44', 83, 8, 18, 146569) I am a Patidar young man of 22 years of age.
('44', 83, 8, 19, 146614) My parents will not hear of my marrying a widow or outside my caste.
('44', 83, 8, 20, 146683) What am I to do in the circumstances?
('44', 83, 8, 21, 146721) I know many a young man who is in the same dilemma as this Patidar youth.
('44', 83, 8, 22, 146795) According to our Shastras, a boy of 16 years and over should be regarded by his parents as a friend whom they should take in their confidence and not as a child whom they can coerce.
('44', 83, 8, 23, 146978) But some parents in our country seem to think that even their grown up children are bound to follow every wish of theirs—especially when it relates to such things as marriage—as if they could have no will of their own in the matter.
('44', 83, 8, 24, 147211) And if this is the attitude with regard to the sons, the plight of the daughters may well be imagined.
('44', 83, 8, 25, 147314) It seems to me that in all such contingencies it is not only the right but the religious duty of young men and young girls not to be afraid of the parents’ wrath.
('44', 83, 8, 26, 147477) It has been my experience that when a grown up boy or girl
('44', 83, 9, 27, 147536) 1 The original Gujarati article appeared in Navajivan 3 2 1929. This is a translation by Pyarelal.

('44', 84, 1, 2, 147680) takes up a just and right position and adheres to it with absolute firm ness there is the least amount of difficulty created by the parents.
('44', 84, 1, 3, 147821) When once they realize that the resolution of their children is absolutely unalterable, they get reconciled to it.
('44', 84, 1, 4, 147936) For behind the parents’ insistence there is always the ultimate hope that it would bring their children to their viewpoint.
('44', 84, 1, 5, 148060) But when this hope is destroyed further insistence becomes meaningless and is therefore given up.
('44', 84, 1, 6, 148158) My advice to the young man in question, therefore, is to refuse to be party to the double sin of marrying a child girl and of conforming to the evil practice of sata.
('44', 84, 1, 7, 148325) He must not mind how much domestic trouble he has to face as a result of his refusal.
('44', 84, 1, 8, 148411) He should consider it a virtue to marry outside his sub caste or to marry a widow, subject to the necessary limitations.

('44', 86, 14, 18, 151580) test, however low it was, was an indifferent and inadequate makeshift which excluded

('44', 86, 17, 22, 151825) Municipality was alive to the elementary needs of the citizens.

('44', 86, 23, 30, 152311) matter of shame for any city not to have a proper supply of pure milk and ghee.

('44', 89, 1, 2, 158248) This argument had some effect on me.
('44', 89, 1, 3, 158285) But it is not my purpose to attempt a real autobiography.
('44', 89, 1, 4, 158343) I simply want to tell the story of my numerous experiments with truth, and as my life consists of nothing but those experiments, it is true that the story will take the shape of an aut obiography.
('44', 89, 1, 5, 158540) But I shall not mind, if every page of it speaks only of my experiments.
('44', 89, 1, 6, 158613) I believe, or at any rate flatter myself with the belief, that a connected account of all these experiments will not be without benefit to the reader.
('44', 89, 1, 7, 158764) My experiments in the political field are now known, not only to India, but to a certain extent to the ‘civilized’ world.
('44', 89, 1, 8, 158886) For me, they have not much value; and the title of ‘Mahatma’ that they have won for me has, therefore, even less.
('44', 89, 1, 9, 159000) Often the title has deeply pained me; and there is not a moment I can recall when it may be said to have tickled me.
('44', 89, 1, 10, 159117) But I should certainly like to narrate my experiments in the spiritual field which are known only to myself, and from which I have derived such power as I possess for working in the political field.
('44', 89, 1, 11, 159316) If the experiments are really spiritual, then there can be no room for self praise.
('44', 89, 1, 12, 159400) They can only add to my humility.
('44', 89, 1, 13, 159434) The more I reflect and look back on the past, the more vividly do I feel my limitations.
('44', 89, 1, 14, 159523) What I want to achieve—what I have been striving and pining to achieve these thirty years—is self realization, to see God face to face, to attain moksha.
('44', 89, 1, 15, 159677) 1 I live and move and have my being in pursuit of this goal.
('44', 89, 1, 16, 159738) All that I do by way of speaking and writing, and all my ventures in the political field, are directed to this same end.
('44', 89, 1, 17, 159859) But as I have all along believed that what is possible for one is possible for all, my experiments have not been conducted in the closet, but in the open; and I do not think that this fact detracts from their spiritual value.
('44', 89, 1, 18, 160085) There are some things which are known only to oneself and one’s Maker.
('44', 89, 1, 19, 160156) These are clearly incommunicable T6. The experiments I am about to relate are not such.
('44', 89, 1, 20, 160244) But they are spiritual, or rather moral; for the essence of religion is morality.
('44', 89, 1, 21, 160326) Only those matters of religion T7 that can be comprehended as much by children as by older people, will be included in this story.
('44', 89, 1, 22, 160457) If I can narrate them in a dispassionate and humble spirit, many other experimenters will find in them provision for their onward march.
('44', 89, 1, 23, 160594) Far be it from me to claim any degree of perfection for these exp eriments.
('44', 89, 1, 24, 160670) I claim for them nothing more than does a scientist who, though he conducts his experiments with the utmost accuracy, fore thought and minuteness, never claims any finality about his con clu sions, but keeps an open mind regarding them.
('44', 89, 1, 25, 160907) I have gone through deep self introspection, searched myself through and through, and
('44', 89, 2, 26, 160993) 1 Literally,‘liberation’; freedom from the phenomenal cycle of birth and death.
('44', 90, 0, 1, 161073) VOL. 44 : 16 JANUARY, 1929 3 FEBRUARY, 1929 91
('44', 90, 1, 2, 161120) examined and analysed every psychological situation.
('44', 90, 1, 3, 161173) Yet I am far from claiming any finality or infallibility about my conclusions.
('44', 90, 1, 4, 161252) One claim I do indeed make and it is this.
('44', 90, 1, 5, 161295) For me they appear to be abs olutely correct, and seem for the time being to be final.
('44', 90, 1, 6, 161382) For if they were not, I should base no action on them.
('44', 90, 1, 7, 161437) But at every step I have carried out the process of acceptance or rejection and acted accordingly.
('44', 90, 1, 8, 161536) And so long as my acts satisfy my reason and my heart, I must firmly adhere to my original conclusions.
('44', 90, 1, 9, 161640) If I had only to discuss academic principles, I should clearly not attempt an autobiography.
('44', 90, 1, 10, 161733) But my purpose being to give an account of various practical applications of these principles, I have given the chapters I propose to write T8 the title of The Story of My Experiments with Truth.
('44', 90, 1, 11, 161929) These will of course include experiments with non viole nce, celibacy and other principles of conduct believed to be distinct from truth.
('44', 90, 1, 12, 162067) But for me, truth is the sovereign principle, which includes num erous other principles.
('44', 90, 1, 13, 162156) This truth is not only truthfulness in word, but truthfulness in thought also, and not only the relative truth of our conception, but the Absolute Truth, the Eternal Principle, that is God.
('44', 90, 1, 14, 162346) There are innumerable definitions of God, because His manifestations are innumerable.
('44', 90, 1, 15, 162432) They overwhelm me with wonder and awe and for a moment stun me.
('44', 90, 1, 16, 162496) But I worship God as Truth only.
('44', 90, 1, 17, 162529) I have not yet found Him, but I am seeking after Him.
('44', 90, 1, 18, 162583) I am prepared to sacrifice the things dearest to me in pursuit of this quest.
('44', 90, 1, 19, 162661) Even if the sacrifice demanded be my very life, I hope I may be prepared to give it.
('44', 90, 1, 20, 162746) But as long as I have not realized this Absolute Truth, so long must I hold by the relative truth as I have conceived it.
('44', 90, 1, 21, 162868) That relative truth must, meanwhile, be my beacon, my shield and buckler.
('44', 90, 1, 22, 162942) Though this path is strait and narrow and sharp as the razor’s edge, for me it has been the quickest and easiest.
('44', 90, 1, 23, 163056) Even my Himalayan blunders have seemed trifling to me because I have kept strictly to this path.
('44', 90, 1, 24, 163153) For the path has saved me from coming to griefT9 , and I have gone forward according to my light.
('44', 90, 1, 25, 163251) Often in my progress I have had faint glimpses of the Absolute Truth, God, and daily the conviction is growing upon me that He alone is real and all else is unreal.
('44', 90, 1, 26, 163416) Let those, who wish T10, realize how the conviction has grown upon me; let them share my experiments and share also my conviction if they can.
('44', 90, 1, 27, 163559) The further conviction has been growing upon me that whatever is possible for me is possible even for a child, and I have sound reasons for saying so.
('44', 90, 1, 28, 163710) The instruments for the quest of truth are as simple as they are difficult.
('44', 90, 1, 29, 163786) They may appear quite impossible to an arrogant person, and quite possible to an innocent child.
('44', 90, 1, 30, 163883) The seeker after truth should be humble than the dust.
('44', 90, 1, 31, 163938) The world crushes the dust under its feet, but the seeker after truth should so humble himself that even the dust
('44', 91, 0, 1, 164052) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 92
('44', 91, 1, 2, 164093) could crush him.
('44', 91, 1, 3, 164110) Only then, and not till then, will he have a glimpse of truth.
('44', 91, 1, 4, 164173) The dialogue 1 between Vasishtha and Vishwamitra makes this abundantly clear.
('44', 91, 1, 5, 164251) Christianity and Islam also amply bear it out.
('44', 91, 1, 6, 164298) If anything that I write in these pages should strike the reader as being touched with pride, then he must take it that there is something wrong with my quest, and that my glimpses are no more than mirage.
('44', 91, 1, 7, 164504) Let hundreds like me perish, but let truth prevail.
('44', 91, 1, 8, 164556) Let us not reduce the standard of truth even by a hair’s breadth for judging erring mortals T11 like myself.
('44', 91, 1, 9, 164665) I hope and pray that no one will regard the advice interspersed in the following chapters as authoritative.
('44', 91, 1, 10, 164773) The experiments narrated should be regarded as illustrations, in the light of which everyone may carry on his own experiments according to his own inclinations and capacity.
('44', 91, 1, 11, 164947) I trust that to this limited extent the illustrations will be really helpful; because I am not going either to conceal or understate any ugly things that must be told.
('44', 91, 1, 12, 165115) I hope to acquaint the reader fully with all my faults and errors.
('44', 91, 1, 13, 165182) My purpose is to describe experiments in the science of satyagraha, not to say how good I am.
('44', 91, 1, 14, 165276) In judging myself I shall try to be as harsh as truth, as I want others also to be T12. Measuring myself by that standard I must exclaim with Surdas : Where is there a wretch So wicked and loathsome as I ?
('44', 91, 1, 15, 165482) I have forsaken my Maker, So faithless have I been.
('44', 91, 1, 16, 165534) For it is an unbroken torture to me that I am still so far from Him, Who as I fully know, governs every breath of my life, and Whose offspring I am T13. I know that it is the evil passions within that keep me so far from Him, and yet I cannot get away from them.
('44', 91, 1, 17, 165797) But I must close.
('44', 91, 1, 18, 165815) I can only take up the actual story in the next chapter.

('44', 96, 1, 2, 177298) CHAPTER III : CHILD MARRIAGE
('44', 96, 2, 3, 177327) Much as I wish that I had not to write this chapter, I know that I shall have to swallow many such bitter draughts in the course of this narrative.
('44', 96, 2, 4, 177475) And I cannot do otherwise, if I claim to be a worshipper of Truth.
('44', 96, 2, 5, 177542) It is my painful duty to have to record here my marriage at the age of thirteen.
('44', 96, 2, 6, 177623) As I see the youngsters of the same age about me who are under my care, and think of my own marriage, I am inclined to pity myself and to congratulate them on having escaped my lot.
('44', 96, 2, 7, 177805) I can see no moral argument in support of such a preposterously early marriage.
('44', 96, 2, 8, 177885) Let the reader make no mistake.
('44', 96, 2, 9, 177917) I was married, not betrothed.
('44', 96, 2, 10, 177947) For in Kathiwad there are two distinct rites—betrothal and marriage.
('44', 96, 2, 11, 178016) Betrothal is a preliminary promise on the part of the parents of the boy and the girl to join them in marriage, and it is not inviolable.
('44', 96, 2, 12, 178154) The death of the boy entails no widowhood on the girl.
('44', 96, 2, 13, 178209) It is an agreement purely between the parents, and the children have no concern with it.
('44', 96, 2, 14, 178298) Often they are not even informed of it.
('44', 96, 2, 15, 178338) It appears that I was betrothed thrice, though without my knowledge.
('44', 96, 2, 16, 178407) I was told that two girls chosen for me had died in turn, and therefore I infer that I was betrothed three times.
('44', 96, 2, 17, 178521) I have a faint recollection, however, that the third betro that took place in my seventh year.
('44', 96, 2, 18, 178616) But I do not recollect having been informed about it.
('44', 96, 2, 19, 178670) T1 In the present chapter I am talking about my marriage, of which I have the clearest recollection.
('44', 96, 2, 20, 178771) It will be remembered that we were three brothers.
('44', 96, 2, 21, 178822) The first was already married.
('44', 96, 2, 22, 178853) The elders decided to marry my second brother, who was two or three years my senior, a cousin, possibly a year older, and me, all at the same time.
('44', 96, 2, 23, 179001) In doing so there was no thought of our welfare, much less our wishes.
('44', 96, 2, 24, 179072) It was purely a question of their own convenience and economy.
('44', 96, 2, 25, 179135) Marriage among Hindus is no simple matter.
('44', 96, 2, 26, 179178) The parents of the bride and the bridegroom often bring themselves to ruin over it.
('44', 96, 2, 27, 179262) They waste their substance, they waste their time.
('44', 96, 2, 28, 179313) Months are taken up over the preparations—in making clothes and ornaments and in preparing budgets for dinners.
('44', 96, 2, 29, 179425) Each tries to outdo the other in the number and variety of courses to be prepared.
('44', 96, 2, 30, 179508) Women, whether they have a voice or no, sing themselves hoarse, even get ill, and disturb the peace of their neighbours.
('44', 96, 2, 31, 179629) These in their turn quietly put up with all the turmoil and bustle, all the dirt and filth, representing the remains of the feasts, because they know that a time will come when they also will be behaving in the same manner.
('44', 96, 2, 32, 179853) It would be better, thought my elders, to have all this bother over at one and the same time.
('44', 96, 2, 33, 179947) Less expense and greater eclat.

('44', 98, 2, 23, 184173) CHAPTER IV : PLAYING THE HUSBAND
('44', 98, 3, 24, 184206) About the time of my marriage, little pamphlets costing a pice, or a pie (I now forget how much), used to be issued, in which conjugal love, thrift, child marriages, and other such subjects were discussed.
('44', 98, 3, 25, 184412) Whenever I came across any of these, I used to go through them cover to cover, and it was a habit with me to forget what I did not like, and to carry out in practice whatever I liked.
('44', 98, 3, 26, 184596) Lifelong faithfulness to the wife, inculcated in these booklets as the duty of the husband, remained permanently imprinted on my heart.
('44', 98, 3, 27, 184732) Furthermore, the passion for truth was innate in me, and to be false to her was therefore out of the question.
('44', 98, 3, 28, 184843) And then there was very little chance of my being faithless at that tender age.
('44', 98, 3, 29, 184923) But the lesson of faithfulness had also an untoward effect.

('44', 150, 2, 6, 321348) ‘Keeping terms’ meant eating one’s terms, i.e., attending at least six out of about twenty four dinners in a term.
('44', 150, 2, 7, 321463) Eating did not mean actually partaking of the dinner, it meant reporting oneself at the fixed hours and remaining present throughout the dinner.
('44', 150, 2, 8, 321608) Usually of course everyone ate and drank the good commons and choice wines pro vided.
('44', 150, 2, 9, 321694) A dinner cost from two and six to three and six, that is from two to three rupees.

('44', 206, 1, 2, 466785) CHAPTER XXI : THE £3 TAX
('44', 206, 2, 3, 466810) Balasundaram’s case brought me into touch with the indentured Indians.
('44', 206, 2, 4, 466881) What impelled me, however, to make a deep study of their condition was the campaign for bringing them under special heavy taxation.
('44', 206, 2, 5, 467013) In the same year, 1894, the Natal Government sought T1 to impose an annual tax of £25 T2 on the indentured Indians.
('44', 206, 2, 6, 467129) The proposal T3 astonished me.
('44', 206, 2, 7, 467160) I put the matter before the Congress for discussion, and it was immediately resolved to organize the necessary opposition.
('44', 206, 2, 8, 467283) At the outset I must explain briefly the genesis of the tax.
('44', 206, 2, 9, 467344) About the year 1860 the Europeans in Natal, finding that there was considerable scope for sugarcane cultivation, felt themselves in need of labour.
('44', 206, 2, 10, 467492) Without outside labour the cultivation of cane and the manufacture of sugar were impossible, as the Natal Zulus were not suited to this form of work.
('44', 206, 2, 11, 467642) The Natal Government therefore corresponded with the Indian Government, and secured their permission to recruit Indian labour.
('44', 206, 2, 12, 467769) These recruits were to sign an indenture to work in Natal for five years, and at the end of the term they were to be at liberty to settle there and to have full rights of ownership of land.
('44', 206, 2, 13, 467959) Those were the inducements held out to them, for the whites then had looked forward to improving their agriculture by the industry of the Indian labourers after the term of their indentures had expired.
('44', 206, 2, 14, 468162) But the Indians gave more than had been expected of them.
('44', 206, 2, 15, 468220) They grew large quantities of vegatables.
('44', 206, 2, 16, 468262) They introduced a number of Indian varieties and made it possible to grow the local varieties cheaper.
('44', 206, 2, 17, 468365) They also introduced the mango.
('44', 206, 2, 18, 468397) Nor did their enterprise stop at agriculture.
('44', 206, 2, 19, 468443) They entered trade.
('44', 206, 2, 20, 468463) They purchased land for building, and many raised themselves from the status of labourers to that of owners of land and houses.
('44', 206, 2, 21, 468591) Merchants from India followed them and settled there for trade.
('44', 206, 2, 22, 468655) The late Sheth Abubakar Amod was first among them.
('44', 206, 2, 23, 468706) He soon built up an extensive business.
('44', 206, 2, 24, 468746) The white traders were alarmed.
('44', 206, 2, 25, 468778) When they first welcomed the Indian labourers, they had not reckoned with their business skill.
('44', 206, 2, 26, 468874) They might be tolerated as independent agriculturists, but their competition in trade could not be brooked.
('44', 206, 2, 27, 468982) This sowed the seed of the antagonism to Indians.
('44', 206, 2, 28, 469032) Many other factors contributed to its growth.
('44', 206, 2, 29, 469078) Our different ways of living, our simplicity, our contentment with small gains, our indifference to the
('44', 207, 0, 1, 469182) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 208
('44', 207, 1, 2, 469224) laws of hygiene and sanitation, our slowness in keeping our surroundings clean and tidy, and our stinginess in keeping our houses in good repair—all these, combined with the difference in religion, contributed to fan the flame of antagonism.
('44', 207, 1, 3, 469466) Through legislation this antagonism found its expression in the disfranchising bill and the bill to impose a tax on the indentured Indians.
('44', 207, 1, 4, 469606) Independent of legislation a number of pinpricks had already been started.
('44', 207, 1, 5, 469681) The first suggestion was that the India labourers should be forcibly repatriated, so that the term of their indentures might expire in India.
('44', 207, 1, 6, 469823) The Government of India was not likely to accept the suggestion.
('44', 207, 1, 7, 469888) Another proposal was therefore made to the effect that 1. the indentured labourer should return to India on the expiry of his indenture; or that 2. he should sign a fresh indenture every two years, an increment being given at each renewal; and that 3. in the case of his refusal to return to India or renew the indenture he should pay an annual tax of £25. ('44', 207, 1, 8, 470372) The Viceroy at that time was Lord Elgin.

('44', 207, 1, 10, 470570) In giving his approval he had in no way thought of the interests of India.
('44', 207, 1, 11, 470645) It was no part of his duty thus to accommodate the Natal Europeans.
('44', 207, 1, 12, 470713) In the course of three of four years an indentured labourer with his wife and each male child over 16 and female child over 13 came under the impost.
('44', 207, 1, 13, 470863) To levy a yearly tax of £12 from a family of four—husband, wife and two children—when the average income of the husband was never more than 14s.
('44', 207, 1, 14, 471008) a month, was atrocious and unknown anywhere else in the world.
('44', 207, 1, 15, 471071) We organized a fierce campaign against this tax.

('44', 207, 1, 20, 471530) In any case it was a breach of trust on the part of the Indian Government.

('44', 208, 1, 2, 471750) the welfare of India the Viceroy ought never to have approved of this inhuman tax.

('44', 252, 2, 16, 589426) Thus service of the Indians in South Africa ever revealed to me new implications of truth at every stage.

('44', 327, 1, 2, 780671) CHAPTER XXVI : THE BIRTH OF SATYAGRAHA
('44', 327, 2, 3, 780710) Events were so shaping themselves in Johannesburg as to make this self purification on my part a preliminary as it were to satyagraha.

('44', 332, 3, 19, 795287) My first experience of jail life was in 1908. I saw that some of the regulations that the prisoners had to observe were such as should be voluntarily observed by a brahmachari, that is, one desiring to practise self restraint.

('44', 355, 2, 3, 853944) I have already referred to the attack of pleurisy I had in England.

('44', 355, 2, 14, 854883) It was no easy thing for me not to yield to Gokhale’s pressure.

('44', 408, 2, 14, 992002) CHAPTER XXI : A PEEP INTO THE ASHRAM
