('44', 410, 1, 2, 995948) CHAPTER XXII : THE FAST
('44', 410, 2, 3, 995972) For the first two weeks the mill hands exhibited great courage and self restraint and daily held monster meetings.
('44', 410, 2, 4, 996087) On these occa sions I used to remind them of their pledge, and they would shout back to me the assurance that they would rather die than break their word.
('44', 410, 2, 5, 996242) But at last they began to show signs of flagging.
('44', 410, 2, 6, 996292) Just as physical weakness in men manifests itself in irascibility, their attitude towards the blacklegs became more and more menacing as the strike seemed to weaken, and I began to fear an outbreak of rowdyism on their part.
('44', 410, 2, 7, 996517) The attendance at their daily meetings also began to dwindle by degrees, and despondency and despair were writ large on the faces of those who did attend.
('44', 410, 2, 8, 996672) Finally the information was brought to me that the strikers had begun to totter.
('44', 410, 2, 9, 996753) I felt deeply troubled and set to thinking furiously as to what my duty was in the circumstances.
('44', 410, 2, 10, 996851) I had had experience of a gigantic strike in South Africa, but the situation that confronted me here was different.
('44', 410, 2, 11, 996967) The mill hands had taken the pledge at my suggestion.
('44', 410, 2, 12, 997021) They had repeated it before me day after day, and the very idea that they might now go back upon it was to me inconceivable.
('44', 410, 2, 13, 997146) Was it pride or was it my love for the labourers and my passionate regard for truth that was at the back of this feeling—who can say ?
('44', 410, 2, 14, 997281) One morning—it was at a mill hands’ meeting—while I was still groping and unable to see my way clearly, the light came to me.
('44', 410, 2, 15, 997407) Unbidden and all by themselves the words came to my lips: ‘Unless the strikers rally’, I declared to the meeting, ‘and continue the strike till a settlement is reached or till they leave the mills altogether,T1 I will not touch any food.’ 1
('44', 410, 3, 16, 997648) The labourersT2 were thunderstruck.

('44', 410, 3, 20, 997829) Please forgive us for our lapse, we will now remain faithful to our pledge to the end.’ ‘There is no need for you to fast,’ I replied.
('44', 410, 3, 21, 997964) ‘It would be enough if you could remain true to your pledge.
('44', 410, 3, 22, 998025) As you know we are without funds, and we do not want to continue our strike by living on public charity.

('44', 411, 1, 10, 999455) As a satyagrahi I knew that I might not fast against them, but ought to leave them free to be influenced by the mill hands’ strike alone.

('44', 412, 1, 9, 1002109) It happened in connection with the distribution of sweets.T5 The mill owners had ordered a very large quantity, and it was a problem how to distribute it among the thousands of labourers.
('44', 412, 1, 10, 1002297) It was decided that it would be the fittest thing to distribute it in the open, beneath the very tree under which the pledge had been taken, especially as it would have been extremely inconvenient to assemble them all together in any other place.
('44', 412, 1, 11, 1002544) IT6 had taken it for granted that the men who had observed strict discipline for full 21 days would without any difficulty be able to remain standing in an orderly manner while the sweets were being distributed, and not make an impatient scramble for them.

('44', 412, 1, 13, 1002899) Again and again their ranks would break into confusion after distribution had proceeded for a couple of minutes.

('44', 412, 1, 16, 1003308) With difficulty we succeeded in taking away the remaining sweets to Sheth Ambalal’s bungalow in Mirzapur.
('44', 412, 1, 17, 1003414) Sweets were distributed comfortably the next day within the compound of that bungalow.
('44', 412, 1, 18, 1003501) The comic side of this incident is obvious, but the pathetic side bears mention.
('44', 412, 1, 19, 1003582) Subsequent inquiry revealed the fact that the beggar population of Ahmedabad, having got scent of the fact that sweets were to be distributed under the Ek Tek tree, had gone there in large numbers, and it was their hungry scramble for the sweets that had created all the confusion and disorder.

('44', 413, 0, 1, 1003934) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('44', 413, 1, 2, 1003976) The grinding poverty and starvation with which our country is afflicted is such that it drives more and more men every year into the ranks of the beggars, whose desperate struggle for bread renders them insensible to all feelings of decency and self respect.
('44', 413, 1, 3, 1004235) And our philanthropists, instead of providing work for them and insisting on their working for bread, give them alms.

('44', 413, 2, 18, 1005973) But the Government was in no mood to listen, and regarded the popular demand for arbitration as lese majeste.

('44', 414, 1, 4, 1006768) The following pledge was signed by the satyagrahis : ‘Knowing that the crops of our villages are less than four annas, we requested the Government to suspend the collection of revenue assessment till the ensuing year, but the Government has not acceded to our prayer.

('44', 416, 1, 19, 1013507) CHAPTER XXV : END OF KHEDA SATYAGRAHA The campaign came to an unexpected end.
('44', 416, 1, 20, 1013585) It was clear that the people were exhausted, and I hesitated to let the unbending be driven to utter ruin.
('44', 416, 1, 21, 1013692) I was casting about for some graceful way of terminating the struggle which would be acceptable to a satyagrahi.

('44', 440, 2, 8, 1077962) CHAPTER XXXIII : ‘A HIMALAYAN MISCALCULATION’
('44', 440, 3, 9, 1078008) Almost immeditely after the Ahmedabad meeting I went to Nadiad.
('44', 440, 3, 10, 1078072) It was here that I first used the expression ‘Himalayan miscalculation’ which obtained such a wide currency afterwards.
('44', 440, 3, 11, 1078192) Even at Ahmeda bad I had begun to have a dim perception of my mistake.
('44', 440, 3, 12, 1078263) But when I reached Nadiad and saw the actual state of things there and heard reports about a large number of people from Kheda district having been arrested, it suddenly dawned upon me that I had com mitted a grave error in calling upon the people in the Kheda district and elsewhere to launch upon civil disobedience prematurely, as it now seemed to me.T1 I was addressing a public meeting.T2 My confession brought down upon me no small amount of ridicule.
('44', 440, 3, 13, 1078721) But I have never regretted having made that confession.
('44', 440, 3, 14, 1078777) For I have always held that it is only when one sees one’s own mistakes with a convex lens, and does just the reverse in the case of others, that one is able to arrive at a just relative estimate of the two.
('44', 440, 3, 15, 1078985) I further believe that a scrupulous and conscientious observance of this rule is necessary for one who wants to be a satyagrahi.
('44', 440, 3, 16, 1079114) Let us now see what that Himalayan miscalculation was.
('44', 440, 3, 17, 1079169) Before one can be fit for the practice of civil disobedience one must have rendered a willing and respectful obedience to the State laws.
('44', 440, 3, 18, 1079307) For the most part we obey such laws out of fear of the penalty for their breach, and this holds good particularly in respect of such laws as do not involve a moral principle.
('44', 440, 3, 19, 1079482) For instance, an honest, respectable man will not suddenly take to stealing, whether there is a law against steal ing or not, but this very man will not feel any remorse for failure to observe the rule about carrying head lights on bicycles after dark.
('44', 440, 3, 20, 1079735) Indeed it is doubtful whether he would even accept advice kindly about being more careful in this respect.
('44', 440, 3, 21, 1079842) But he would observe any obligatory rule of this kind, if only to escape the inconvenience of facing a prosecution for a breach of the rule.
('44', 440, 3, 22, 1079983) Such compliance is not, however, the willing and spontaneous obedience that is required of a satyagrahi.
('44', 440, 3, 23, 1080088) A satyagrahi obeys the laws of society intelligently and of
('44', 441, 0, 1, 1080148) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 442
('44', 441, 1, 2, 1080190) his own free will, because he considers it to be his sacred duty to do so.
('44', 441, 1, 3, 1080265) It is only when a person has thus obeyed the laws of society scrupulously that he is in a position to judge as to which particular rules are good and just and which unjust and iniquitous.
('44', 441, 1, 4, 1080453) Only then does the right accrue to him of the civil disobedience of certain laws in well defined circumstances.
('44', 441, 1, 5, 1080565) My error lay in my faliure to observe this necessary limitation.T3 I had called on the people to launch upon civil disobedience before they had thus qualified themselves for it, and this mistake seemed to me of Himalayan magnitude.
('44', 441, 1, 6, 1080797) As soon as I entered the Kheda district, all the old recollections of the Kheda Satyagraha struggle came back to me, and I wondered how I could have failed to perceive what was so obvious.
('44', 441, 1, 7, 1080986) I realized that before a people could be fit for offering civil disobedience, they should thoroughly understand its deeper implications.T4 That being so, before restartingT5 civil disobedience on a mass scale, it would be necessary to create a band of well tried,T6 pure hearted volunteers who thoroughly understood the strict conditions of satyagraha.
('44', 441, 1, 8, 1081339) They could explain these to the people, and by sleepless vigilance keep them on the right path.
('44', 441, 1, 9, 1081435) With these thoughts filling my mind I reached Bombay, raised a corps of satyagrahi volunteers through the Satyagraha Sabha there, and with their help commenced the work of educating the people with regard to the meaning and inner significance of satyagraha.
('44', 441, 1, 10, 1081693) This was princi pally done by issuing leaflets of an educative character bearing on the subject.
('44', 441, 2, 11, 1081790) But whilst this work was going on, I could see that it was a difficult task to interest the people in the peaceful side of satyagraha.

('44', 444, 2, 10, 1089369) CHAPTER XXXV : IN THE PUNJAB
('44', 444, 3, 11, 1089398) Sir Michael O’Dwyer held me responsible for all that had happened in the Punjab, and some irate young Punjabis held me responsibleT1 for the martial law.
('44', 444, 3, 12, 1089552) They asserted that, if only I had not suspended civil disobedience, there would have been no Jallianwala Bagh massacreT2. Some of them even went the length of threatening me with assassination if I went to the Punjab.
('44', 444, 3, 13, 1089770) But I felt that my position was so correct and above question that no intelligent person could misunderstand it.
('44', 444, 3, 14, 1089883) I was impatient to go to the Punjab.
('44', 444, 3, 15, 1089920) I had never been there before, and that made me all the more anxious to see things for myself.
('44', 444, 3, 16, 1090015) Dr. Satyapal, Dr. Kitchlew and Pandit Rambhaj Dutt Cho wdhari, who had invited me to the Punjab,T3 were at this time in jail.
('44', 444, 3, 17, 1090141) But I felt sure that the Government could not dare to keep them and the other prisonersT4 in prison for long.
('44', 444, 3, 18, 1090251) A large number of Punjabis used to come and see me whenever I was in Bombay.
('44', 444, 3, 19, 1090328) I ministered to them a word of cheer on these occasions, and that would comfort them.
('44', 444, 3, 20, 1090414) My self confidence of that time was infectious.T5 But my going to the Punjab had to be postponed again and again.
('44', 444, 3, 21, 1090528) The Viceroy would say, ‘not yet’, every time I asked for permission to go there, and so the thing dragged on.
('44', 444, 3, 22, 1090638) In the meantime the Hunter Committee was announced to hold

('44', 445, 1, 2, 1090739) an inquiry in connection with the Punjab Government’s doings under the martial law.

('44', 445, 1, 5, 1091063) He pressed me urgently to come and join him.
('44', 445, 1, 6, 1091108) At the same time Malaviyaji sent telegrams asking me to proceed to the Punjab at once.

('44', 445, 1, 8, 1091276) He wired back in reply that I could go there after a certain date.
('44', 445, 1, 9, 1091343) I cannot exactly recollect now, but I think it was 17th 1 of October.
('44', 445, 1, 10, 1091413) The scene that I witnessed on my arrival at Lahore can never be effaced from my memory.
('44', 445, 1, 11, 1091501) The railway station was from end to end one seething mass of humanity.
('44', 445, 1, 12, 1091572) The entire populace had turned out of doors in eager expectation, as if to meet a dear relation after a long separation, and was delirious with joy.
('44', 445, 1, 13, 1091721) I was put up at the late Pandit Rambhaj Dutt’s bungalow, and the burden of entertaining me fell on the shoulders of Shrimati Sarala DeviT6. A burden it truly was, for even then, as now, the place where I was accommodated became a veritable caravanserai.

('44', 445, 1, 16, 1092305) All these leaders, as also such local leaders as had escaped the privilege of going to jail, at once made me feel perfectly at home amongst them, so that I never felt like a stranger in their midst.
('44', 445, 1, 17, 1092504) How we unanimously decided not to lead evidence before the Hunter Committee is now a matter of history.T8 The reasons for that decision were published at that time, and need not be recapitulated here.
('44', 445, 1, 18, 1092705) Suffice it to say that, looking back upon these events from this distance of time, I still feel that our decision to boycott the Committee was absolutely correct and proper.
('44', 445, 2, 19, 1092879) As a logical consequence of the boycott of the Hunter Com mitttee, it was decided to appoint a non official Inquiry Committee, to hold almost a parallel inquiry on behalf of the Congress.

('44', 446, 1, 3, 1093544) The responsibility for organizing the work of the Committee devolved on me, and as the privilege of conducting the inquiry in the largest number of places fell to my lot, I got a rare opportunity of observing at close quarters the people of the Punjab and the Punjab villages.
('44', 446, 1, 4, 1093821) In the course of my inquiry I made acquaintance with the women of the Punjab also.
('44', 446, 1, 5, 1093904) It was as if we had known one another for ages.
('44', 446, 1, 6, 1093952) Wherever I went they came flocking, and laid before me their heaps of yarn.
('44', 446, 1, 7, 1094028) My work in connection with the inquiry brought home to me the fact that the Punjab could become a great field for khadi work.
('44', 446, 1, 8, 1094154) As I proceeded further and further with my inquiry into the atrocities that had been committed on the people, I came across tales of Government’s tyranny and the arbitrary despotism of its officers such as I was hardly prepared for, and they filled me with deep pain.
('44', 446, 1, 9, 1094422) What surprised me then, and what still continues to fill me with surprise, was the fact that a province that had furnished the largest number of soldiers to the British Government during the War, should have taken all these brutal excesses lying down.
('44', 446, 1, 10, 1094674) The task of drafting the report 1 of this Committee was also entrusted to me.
('44', 446, 1, 11, 1094752) I would recommend a perusal of this report to anyone who wants to have an idea of the kind of atrocities that were perpetrated on the Punjab people.
('44', 446, 1, 12, 1094901) All that I wish to say here about it is that there is not a single conscious exaggeration in it anywhere, and every statement made in it is substantiated by evidence.
('44', 446, 1, 13, 1095068) Moreover, the evidence published was only a fraction of what was in the Com mittee’s possession.
('44', 446, 1, 14, 1095165) Not a single statement, regarding the validity of which there was the slightest room for doubt, was permitted to appear in the report.
('44', 446, 1, 15, 1095300) This report, prepared as it was solely with a view to bringing out the truth and nothing but the truth, will enable the reader to see to what lengths the British Government is capable of going, and what inhumanities and barbarities it is capable of perpetrating in order to maintain its power.
('44', 446, 1, 16, 1095594) So far as I am aware, not a single statement made in this report has ever been disproved.
('44', 446, 2, 17, 1095684) CHAPTER XXXVI : THE KHILAFAT AGAINST COW PROTECTION ?
('44', 446, 3, 18, 1095738) We must now leave for the time being these dark happenings in the Punjab.

('44', 447, 1, 2, 1096120) to deliberate on the Khilafat question.T1 Among the signatories to it were the late Hakim Ajmal Khan Saheb and Mr. Asaf Ali.

('44', 447, 1, 4, 1096467) The confe rence was to deliberate on the situation arising out of the Khilafat betra yal, and on the question as to whether the Hindus and Mussalmans should take any part in the peace celebrations.
('44', 447, 1, 5, 1096665) The letter of invitation went on to say, among other things, that not only the Khilafat question but the question of cow protection as well would be discussed at the conference, and it would, therefore, afford a golden opportunity for a settlement of the cow question.
('44', 447, 1, 6, 1096934) I did not like this reference to the cow question.
('44', 447, 1, 7, 1096985) In my letter in reply to the invitation, therefore, whilst promising to do my best to attend, I suggested that the two questions should not be mixed up together or considered in the spirit of a bargain, but should be decided on their own merits and treated separately.
('44', 447, 1, 8, 1097254) With these thoughts filling my mind,T2 I went to the conference.
('44', 447, 1, 9, 1097319) It was a very well attended gathering, though it did not present the spectacle of later gatherings that were attended by tens of thousands.
('44', 447, 1, 10, 1097459) I discussed the question referred to above with the late Swami Shraddhanandji, who was present at the conference.
('44', 447, 1, 11, 1097573) He appreciated my argument and left it to me to place it before the conference.
('44', 447, 1, 12, 1097653) I likewise discussed it with the late Hakim Saheb.
('44', 447, 1, 13, 1097704) Before the conference I contended that, if the Khilafat question had a just and legitimate basis, as I believe it had, and if the Government had really committed a gross injustice, the Hindus were bound to stand by the Mussalmans in their demand for the redress of the Khilafat wrong.
('44', 447, 1, 14, 1097989) It would ill bec ome them to bring in the cow question in this connection, or to use the occasion to make terms with the Mussalmans, just as it would ill become the Mussalmans to offer to stop cow slaughter as a price for the Hindus’ support on the Khilafat question.
('44', 447, 1, 15, 1098257) But it would be another matter and quite graceful, and reflect great credit on them, if the Mussalmans of their own free will stopped cow slaughter out of regard for the religious sentiments of the Hindus, and from a sense of duty towards them as neighbours and children of the same soil.
('44', 447, 1, 16, 1098546) To take up such an independent attitude was, I contended, their duty, and would enhance the dignity of their conduct.
('44', 447, 1, 17, 1098664) But if the Mussalmans considered it as their neighbourly duty to stop cow slaughter, they should do so regardless of whether the Hindus helped them in the Khilafat or not.
('44', 447, 1, 18, 1098836) ‘That being so,’ I argued, ‘the two questions should be discussed independently of each other, and the deliberations of the

('44', 448, 2, 3, 1099202) But in spite of my warning Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb said : ‘No matter whether the Hindus help us or not, the Mussalmans ought, as the countrymen of the Hindus, out of regard for the latter’s susceptibilities, to give up cow slaughter.’ And at one time it almost looked as if they would really put an end to it.

('44', 448, 2, 12, 1100565) His object was to wreak vengeance on the British Empire, in case justice was denied in the matter of the Khilafat.

('44', 450, 2, 15, 1105881) CHAPTER XXXVII : THE AMRITSAR CONGRESS
('44', 450, 3, 16, 1105920) The Punjab Government could not keep in confinement the hundreds of Punjabis who, under the martial law regime, had been clapped into jail on the strength of the most meagre evidence by tribunals that were courts only in name.

('44', 460, 1, 13, 1133430) What we need is not propaganda to inflate demand for our goods, but greater production.’ ‘Then, surely, you will bless my effort, if I am already engaged in that very thing,’ I asked.
('44', 460, 1, 14, 1133614) ‘How can that be ?’ he exclaimed, a bit puzzled, ‘but may be, you are thinking of promoting the establishment of new mills, in which case you certainly deserve to be congratulated.’ ‘I am not doing exactly that,’ I explained, ‘but I am engaged in the revival of the spinning wheel.’ ‘What is that ?’ he asked, feeling still more at sea.T5 I told him all about the spinning wheel, and the story of my long quest after it, and added, ‘I am entirely of your opinion, it is no use my becoming virtually an agent for the mills.
('44', 460, 1, 15, 1134137) That would do more harm than good to the country.
('44', 460, 1, 16, 1134187) Our mills will not be in want of custom for a long time to come.T6 My work should be, and therefore is, to organize the production of hand spun cloth, and to find means for the disposal of the khadi thus produced.
('44', 460, 1, 17, 1134401) I am, therefore, concentrating my attention on the production of khadi.
('44', 460, 1, 18, 1134473) I swear by this form of swadeshi, because through it I can provide work to the semi starved, semi employed women of India.
('44', 460, 1, 19, 1134596) My idea is to get these women to spin yarn, and to clothe the people of India with khadi woven out of it.
('44', 460, 1, 20, 1134702) I do not know
('44', 461, 0, 1, 1134716) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 462
('44', 461, 1, 2, 1134758) how far this movement is going to succeed; at present it is only in the incipient stage.
('44', 461, 1, 3, 1134847) But I have full faith in it.
('44', 461, 1, 4, 1134876) At any rate it can do no harm.
('44', 461, 1, 5, 1134907) On the contrary to the extent that it can add to the cloth production of the country be it ever so small, it will represent so much solid gain.
('44', 461, 1, 6, 1135051) You will thus perceive that my movement is free from the evils mentioned by you.’ He replied, ‘If you have additional production in view inT7 organizing your movement, I have nothing to say against it.

('44', 461, 2, 9, 1135391) CHAPTER XLII : ITS RISING TIDET1
('44', 461, 3, 10, 1135424) I must not devote any more chapters here to a description of the further progress of khadi.
('44', 461, 3, 11, 1135516) It would be outside the scope of these chapters to give a history of my various activities after they came before the public eye, and I must not attempt it, if only because to do so would require a treatise on the subject.
('44', 461, 3, 12, 1135739) My object in writing these chapters is simply to describe how certain things, as it were spon taneously, presented themselves to me in the course of my exper iments with truth.
('44', 461, 3, 13, 1135916) To resume, then, the story of the non co operation movement.
('44', 461, 3, 14, 1135977) Whilst the powerful Khilafat agitation set up by the Ali Brothers was in full progress, I had long discussions on the subject with the late Maulana Abdul Bari and the other ulemas, especially, with regard to the extent to which a Mussalman could observe the rule of non violence.
('44', 461, 3, 15, 1136257) In the end they all agreed that Islam did not forbid its followers from following non violence as a policyT2, and further, that, while they were pledged to that policy, they were bound faithfully to carry it out.
('44', 461, 3, 16, 1136470) At last the non co operation resolution was moved in the Khilafat conference, and carried after prolonged deliberations.

('44', 461, 3, 18, 1136699) In the beginning the late Hakim Saheb was sceptical as to the practicability of non violent non co operation.
('44', 461, 3, 19, 1136809) But after his scepticism was overcome he threw himself into it heart and soul, and his help proved invaluable to the movement.
('44', 461, 3, 20, 1136936) Next, the non co operation resolution was moved by me at the Gujarat Political Conference that was held shortly afterwards.
('44', 461, 3, 21, 1137060) The preliminary contention raised by the opposition was that it was not competent to a provincial conference to adopt a resolution in advance of the Congress.
('44', 461, 3, 22, 1137219) As against this, I suggested that the restriction could apply only to a backward movement; but as for going forward, the subordinate organizations were not only fully competent, but were in duty bound to do so, if they had in them the necessary grit and

('44', 462, 1, 2, 1137521) confidence.
('44', 462, 1, 3, 1137533) No permision, I argued, was needed to try to enhance the prestige of the parent institution, provided one did it at one’s own risk.T3 The proposition was then discussed on its merits, the debate being marked by its keenness no less than the atmosphere of ‘sweet reasonableness’ in which it was conducted.
('44', 462, 1, 4, 1137838) On the ballot being taken the resolution was declared carried by an overwhelming majority.

('44', 462, 1, 6, 1138018) Vallabhbhai and Abbas Tyabji.

('44', 462, 1, 9, 1138296) Preparations were made for it on a large scale.

('44', 462, 1, 15, 1138712) I invariably made use of this word in my speeches.
('44', 462, 1, 16, 1138763) My vocabulary on the subject was still in process of formation.T4 I found that I could not bring home my meaning to purely Muslim audiences with the help of the Sanskrit equivalent for non violent.
('44', 462, 1, 17, 1138961) I therefore asked Maulana Abul Kalam Azad to give me some other equivalent for it.

('44', 462, 1, 19, 1139146) Thus, while I was still busy devising suitable Hindi, Gujarati and Urdu phraseology for non co operation, I was called upon to frame the non co operation resolution for that eventful Congress.
('44', 462, 1, 20, 1139339) In the original draft the word ‘non violent’ had been left out by me.

('44', 463, 1, 2, 1140267) saw an imposing phalanx of veteran warriors assembled for the fray at Calcutta,T5 Dr. Besant, Pandit Malaviyaji, Sjt.

('44', 464, 1, 3, 1143024) CHAPTER XLIII : AT NAGPUR The resolutions adopted at the Calcutta special session of the Congress were to be confirmed at its annual session at Nagpur.
('44', 464, 1, 4, 1143176) Here again, as at Calcutta there was a great rush of visitors and delegates.
('44', 464, 1, 5, 1143253) The number of delegates in the Congress had not been limited yet.
('44', 464, 1, 6, 1143319) As a result, so far as I can remember, the figure on this occasion reached about fourteen thousand.
('44', 464, 1, 7, 1143419) Lalaji pressed for a slight amendment to the clause about the boycott of schools, which I accepted.
('44', 464, 1, 8, 1143519) Similarly some amendments were made at the instance of the Deshbandhu, after which the non co operation resolutionT1 was passed unanimously.
('44', 464, 2, 9, 1143660) The resolution regarding the revision of the Congress consti tution too was to be taken up at this session of the Congress.
('44', 464, 2, 10, 1143784) The sub committee’s draft was presented at the Calcutta special session.
('44', 464, 2, 11, 1143857) The matter had therefore been thoroughly ventilated and thrashed out.
('44', 464, 2, 12, 1143927) At the Nagpur session, where it came up for final disposal,T2 Sjt.
('44', 464, 2, 13, 1143994) C. Vijayaraghavachari was the President.
('44', 464, 2, 14, 1144035) The Subjects Committee passed the draft with only one important change.
('44', 464, 2, 15, 1144107) In my draft the number of delegates had been fixed, I think, at 1,500; the Subjects Committee substituted in its place the figure 6,000. In my opinion this increase was the result of hasty judgment, and experience of all these years has only confirmed me in my view.
('44', 464, 2, 16, 1144374) I hold it to be an utter delusion to believe that a large number of delegates is in any way a help to the better conduct of the business, or that it safeguards the principle of democracy.
('44', 464, 2, 17, 1144562) Fifteen hundred delegates, jealous of the interest of the people, broad minded and truthful, would any day be a better safeguard for democracy than six thousand irresponsible men chosen anyhow.
('44', 464, 2, 18, 1144756) To safeguard democracy the people must have a keen sense of independence, self respect and their oneness, and should insist upon choosing as their representatives only such persons as are good and true.
('44', 464, 2, 19, 1144959) But obsessed with the idea of numbers as the Subjects Committee was, it would have liked to go even beyond the figure of six thousand.
('44', 464, 2, 20, 1145094) The limit of six thousand was therefore in the nature of a compromise.
('44', 464, 2, 21, 1145165) The question of the goal of the congress formed a subject for keen discussion.
('44', 464, 2, 22, 1145244) In the constitution that I had presented, the goal of the Congress was the attainment of swaraj within the British Empire if pos sible and without if necessary.
('44', 464, 2, 23, 1145405) A party in the Congress wanted to limit the goal to swaraj within the British Empire only.
('44', 464, 2, 24, 1145496) Its viewpoint

('44', 465, 1, 3, 1145801) But they were not able to get many votes.
('44', 465, 1, 4, 1145843) Again the draft constitution provided that the means for the attainment were to be peaceful and legitimate.

('44', 465, 2, 11, 1146984) FAREWELL The time has now come to bring these chapters to a close.
('44', 465, 3, 12, 1147051) My life from this point onward has been so public that there is hardly anything about it that people do not know.
('44', 465, 3, 13, 1147165) Moreover, since 1921 I have worked in such close association with the Congress leaders that I can hardly describeT1 any episode in my life since then without referring to my relations with them.T2 For though Shradd hanandji, the Deshbandhu, Hakim Saheb and Lalaji are no more with us today, we have the good luck to have a host of other veteran Congress leaders still living and working in our midst.
('44', 465, 3, 14, 1147566) The history of the Congress, since the great changes in it that I have described above, is still in the making.

('44', 466, 1, 11, 1149221) To describe truth, as it has appeared to me, and in the exact manner in which I have arrived at it, has been my ceaseless effort.
('44', 466, 1, 12, 1149351) The exercise has given me ineffable mental peace, because, it has been my fond hope that it might bring faith in Truth and Ahimsa to waverers.T5 My uniform experience has convinced me that there is no other God than Truth.
('44', 466, 1, 13, 1149574) And if every page of these chapters does not proclaim to the reader that the only means for the realization of Truth is Ahimsa, I shall deem all my labour in writing these chapters to have been in vain.
('44', 466, 1, 14, 1149777) And, even though my efforts in this behalf may prove fruitless, let the readers know that the vehicle, not the great principle, is at fault.T6 After all, however sincere my strivings after Ahimsa may have been, they have still been imperfect and inadequate.
('44', 466, 1, 15, 1150035) The little fleeting glimpses, therefore, that I have been able to have of Truth can hardly convey an idea of the indescribable lustre of Truth, a million times more intense than that of the sun we daily see with our eyes.
('44', 466, 1, 16, 1150257) In fact what I have caught is only the faintest glimmer of that mighty effulgence.
('44', 466, 1, 17, 1150340) But this much I can say with assurance, as a result of all my experiments, that a perfect vision of Truth can only follow a complete realization of Ahimsa.
('44', 466, 1, 18, 1150496) To see the universal and all pervading Spirit of Truth face to face one must be able to love the meanest of creation as oneself.
('44', 466, 1, 19, 1150625) And a man who aspires after that cannot afford to keep out of any field of life.
('44', 466, 1, 20, 1150706) That is why my devotion to Truth has drawn me into the field of politics; and I can say without the slightest hesitation, and yet in all humility, that those who say that religion has nothing to do with politics do not know what religion means.
('44', 466, 1, 21, 1150951) Identification with everything that lives is impossible without self purification; without self purification the observance of the law of Ahimsa must remain an empty dream.
('44', 466, 1, 22, 1151124) God can never be realized by one who is not pure of heart.
('44', 466, 1, 23, 1151183) Self purification therefore must mean purification in all the walks of life.T7 And purification being highly
('44', 467, 0, 1, 1151292) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 468
('44', 467, 1, 2, 1151334) infectious, purification of oneself necessarily leads to the purification of one’s surroundings.T8 ButT9 the path of self purification is hard and steep.
('44', 467, 1, 3, 1151488) To attain to perfect purity one has to become absolutely passion free in thought, speech and action; to rise above the opposing currents of love and hatred, attachment and repulsion.
('44', 467, 1, 4, 1151671) I know that I have not in me as yet that triple purity, in spite of constant ceaseless striving for it.
('44', 467, 1, 5, 1151775) That is why the world’s praise fails to move me, indeed it very often stings me.
('44', 467, 1, 6, 1151856) To conquer the subtle passions seems to me to be harder far than the physical conquest of the world by the force of arms.
('44', 467, 1, 7, 1151978) Ever sinceT10 my return to India I have had experiences of the dormant passions lying hidden within me.
('44', 467, 1, 8, 1152082) The knowledge of them has made me feel humiliated though not defeated.
('44', 467, 1, 9, 1152153) The experiences and experiments have sustained me and given me great joy.T11 But I know that I have still before me a difficult path to traverse.
('44', 467, 1, 10, 1152299) I must reduce myself to zero.
('44', 467, 1, 11, 1152329) So long as a man does not of his own free will put himself last among his fellow creatures, there is no salvation for him.
('44', 467, 1, 12, 1152452) Ahimsa is the farthest limit of humility.T12 In bidding farewell to the reader, for the time being at any rate, I ask him to join with me in prayer to the God of Truth that He may grant me the boon of Ahimsa in mind, word and deed.T13
